questions.text: The following findings are seen in a man who presents to the OPD. The CT scan of his neck is given below. Which of the following situations is not at the risk of being converted to an open sternotomy during surgery?

choices.text: If this is a case of revision surgery
Diameter of goiter is more than thoracic inlet
If the swelling extends into the anterior mediastinum

questions.solution:
The two images(A&B) show a positive Pemberton’s sign, which is indicative of a Superior Vena Cava Syndrome. The CT scan shows a large thyroid goiter and extension into the mediastinum (retrosternal extension).

Most of the retrosternal goiters (>95%) are removed transcervically.

Those at most risk of conversion into an open sternotomy are:

  • Malignant swellings
  • Revision surgery
  • Diameter of goiter is more than thoracic inlet
  • Swelling extends into posterior mediastinum

Pemberton's sign is positive when bilateral arm elevation causes facial plethora. It has been attributed to a "cork effect" resulting from the thyroid obstructing the thoracic inlet, thereby increasing pressure on the venous system.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset of massive, painless, recurrent hematemesis with hypotension. Endoscopy shows the following lesion in the stomach. Histologic section shows a tortuous artery in the submucosa. On angiography the ectatic artery is commonly found in the distribution of?
questions.solution:
Sudden hematemesis with the presence of a dilated tortuous artery in the submucosa in the stomach is indicative of Dieulafoy’s lesion.

On angiography the ectatic artery is commonly found  in the distribution of left gastric artery.

Dieulafoy's lesion is aberrant vessel in mucosa that bleeds from a mucosal defect.Occurs 6-10 cm from GE junction ,generally in fundus near cardia along lesser curvature.

Clinical features:

  • Sudden onset of massive,painless ,recurrent hematemesis with hypotension.
  • recurrent bleeding with spontaneous cessation is common.

Treatment:

  • Intial attempts at endoscopic control are often successful 
  • Application of thermal or sclerosant therapy is effective in 80-100% of cases.
  • Endoscopic therapy failure ,angiographic coil embolization can be successful.
  • When other modalities have failed,Gastric wedge resection to include the offending vessel is reserved.

Dieulafoy’s lesion also occurs in

  • Stomach – 71%
  • Duodenum – 15%
  • Oesophagus – 8%
  • Rectum – 2%
  • Colon – 2%

questions.text: A 35-year-old met with a road traffic accident and was brought to the emergency department.On examination, patient is conscious ,oriented with a  depressed skull fracture and a clean overlying scalp laceration. There was no gross contamination of the wound. CT scan revealed that the degree of depression was less than the thickness of adjacent skull bone. There were no focal neurological deficits and the patient is stable. What is the next step in the management of the patient?

choices.text: Surgically elevate the depressed segment and close the laceration with sutures
Provide prophylactic antibiotics and discharge the patient
Apply dressing and discharge the patient

questions.solution:
The next step is to close the laceration with suture.

The management of the depressed skull fractures:

The first step is to order a CT scan to know the degree of depression and to exclude the presence of an intracranial hematoma or contusion.

The depressed fracture is elevated and managed as an open fracture if:

  • The degree of depression is greater than the thickness of the adjacent skull
  • The wound is are open and grossly contaminated
  • There are focal neurological deficits

Less severe depressed fractures are managed by the closure of the overlying scalp laceration, if present.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild brain injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate brain injury
  • scores ≤8 represent severe brain injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal/flexion 4
Abnormal flexion/Decorticate posturing  3
Extension/Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • The motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils Unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

 

Related Pearl: NICE Guidelines for CT in Head Injury

National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) Guidelines for Computed Tomography (CT) in Head Injury

Indications for CT imaging within 1 hour of following risk factors being identified:

  • Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) <13 at any point
  • GCS <15 at 2 hours after injury on assessment in emergency department
  • Focal neurological deficit
  • Suspected open, depressed, or basal skull fracture
  • More than one episode of vomiting
  • Post-traumatic seizure

Indications for CT imaging within 8 hours

  • Age >65 years
  • Coagulopathy (e.g., aspirin, warfarin, or rivaroxaban use)
  • Dangerous mechanism of injury (e.g., fall from a height, road traffic accident)
  • Retrograde amnesia >30 minutes

questions.text: A 48-year-old patient presented with scrotal swelling. Following orchidectomy, the following histological picture was observed. Which of the following tumor markers would not have been elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The history and the given histology picture (fried-egg appearance) are highly suggestive of testicular seminoma.

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is never raised in pure seminomas.

 Note:

 Alpha-fetoprotein AFP:

  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Yolk sac tumor
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Mixed germ cell tumor
  •  AFP is never raised in pure seminomas or pure choriocarcinoma

human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG): Only the β subunit is measured by the most commonly available serum assays. Can be raised in

  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Seminoma
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • LDH has limited sensitivity and specificity for seminoma, but LDH levels >2000 U/L are more consistent with bulky disease, and rising levels are an accurate indicator of recurrence.
  •  In non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors (NSCGT), LDH is directly related to tumor burden.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male, who is a known case of PVD, comes with complaints of rest pain. Which of the following values of ankle and brachial pressure correspond to the values that can be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
An ABPI of <0.5 is associated with rest pain. The ABPI of 0.4, seen in case of option D, Ankle - 48/36mm Hg, Brachial - 120/80mm Hg, will be corresponding to that of rest pain.

ABPI = Systolic Pressure at Ankle/ Systolic Pressure in the arm(Brachial)

=48/120 = 0.4

 

Other options:

A - ABPI =1.25

B - ABPI = 1

C - ABPI = 0.75

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The highest pressure is in the dorsalispedis, posterior tibial or peroneal artery that serves as the numerator, with the highest brachial systolic pressure being the denominator.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.91 < 1.3 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.5 Rest pain
<0.3 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female came to OPD with a history of a lump in the right breast. On clinical examination, the size of the lump in the right breast is 5 × 6 cm and has right-side interpectoral axillary lymphadenopathy. Interpectoral axillary lymph node belongs to ___________

choices.text: Level 1 group of axillary lymph nodes
Level 3 group of axillary lymph nodes
Level 2 group of axillary lymph nodes

questions.solution:
Interpectoral lymph nodes are classified under level 2 (deep) group of axillary lymph nodes.

Lymph nodes are divided into different levels on the basis of their relation to the pectoralis minor.

  • Level 1 lymph nodes: Lateral to the pectoralis minor (anterior, lateral, and posterior/subscapular groups)
  • Level 2 lymph nodes: Superficial or deep to the pectoralis minor (central and interpectoral groups)
  • Level 3 lymph nodes: Medial to the pectoralis minor (apical/subclavicular group)

Related Pearl: Lymphatic drainage of breast

The lymphatics of the breast drain predominantly into

  • The axillary lymph nodes (85%)
  • Internal mammary lymph nodes
  • Posterior intercostal/Interpectoral/ Rotter’s lymph nodes

The axillary nodes are arranged in the following groups:

Level I (Lymph nodes located lateral to pectoralis minor muscle):

  • Lateral, along the axillary vein - drains most of upper limb
  • Anterior (external mammary group or pectoral group), along the lateral thoracic vessels - drains most of breast.(1st relay station for lymph)
  • Posterior (scapular group), along the subscapular vessels

Level II (Lymph nodes located superficial or deep to pectoralis minor muscle):

  • Central, embedded in fat in the centre of the axilla- receive drainage from Level I groups

Level III (Lymph nodes located medial to pectoralis minor muscle):

  • Apical (sub-clavicular group), which lie above the level of the pectoralis minor tendon in continuity with the lateral nodes and which receive the efferents of all the other axillary groups and drains in to subclavian lymphatic trunk.

Interpectoral (Rotters node) - a few nodes lying between the pectoralis major and minor muscles.(Level II)

Internal mammary nodes drain posterior one-third of breast.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male was diagnosed with rectal prolapse. The operating surgeon decided to perform surgery by an abdominal approach. The procedure is likely to be:
questions.solution:
Resection rectopexy is a surgical procedure performed for rectal prolapse by the abdominal approach.

Surgical Management of Rectal Prolapse:

Perineal approach:

  • Thiersch operation
  • Delorme's operation
  • Altemeier's procedure

Abdominal approach:

  • Suture rectopexy (suturing the rectum to the sacrum)
  • Resection rectopexy (rectopexy with resection of the sigmoid colon)
  • Mesh rectopexy (a strip of mesh sutures to the anterior rectum, with the upper end of the mesh at the sacral promontory)

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a known case of diverticulosis presents to the emergency department with pain abdomen. On per abdominal examination, there is guarding and rigidity. During laparotomy, a diverticular perforation is seen with purulent peritonitis.  What is the Hinchey's stage in this case?
questions.solution:
Purulent peritonitis belongs to stage 3 in the Hinchey classification.

Hinchey classification is the most commonly used classification for the severity and complication of acute diverticulitis. It is used additionally to guide the overall management of acute diverticulitis. 

Hinchey classification of complicated diverticulitis.

Stage 1

Mesenteric or pericolic abscess

Stage 2

Pelvic abscess

Stage 3

Purulent peritonitis

Stage 4

Fecal peritonitis

questions.text: Identify the following instrument that is inserted  after the exploration of  common bile duct.
questions.solution:
The image shows Kehr's T tube with the vertical and horizontal limbs.

Kehr's T tube is used after the exploration of common bile duct i.e. horizontal limb is placed in the common bile duct and vertical limb is brought out as drain. It allows bile to drain while the sphincter of Oddi is in spasm postoperatively. Once the sphincter relaxes, bile drains normally down the bile duct and into the duodenum.

Common bile duct T-tubes should remain in for 10 days. The 10-day period is required to minimize the risk of biliary peritonitis after removal. However, once the T-tube cholangiogram has shown that there is a free flow of bile into the duodenum and that there are no retained stones. some surgeons like to clamp the T-tube prior to removal.

Other options:

Option B: Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is used to provide temporary hemostasis. It causes hemostasis by providing tamponade at the oesophagogastric junction.

Option C: Dobhoff tube is used for providing enteral nutrition.

Option D: Minnesota tube has 4 openings, 2 suction tubes, and 2 inflation tubes. Suction tubes allow aspiration of both gastric and oesophageal contents.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man sustained a road traffic accident and has a large wound on the thigh. After initial wound management, the plastic surgeon decides to cover the wound with a split skin graft. The order by which split skin graft survives is by_________
questions.solution:
Split skin graft survives by imbibition- inosculation-neovascularization.

Split skin graft survives the transplantation surgery by the following process:

  • The graft survives the first 48 hours because of the imbibition of plasma from the wound bed.
  • After 48 hours, fine anastomotic connections are made, which leads to the inosculation of blood.
  • Neovascularization is the process by which new blood vessels formed will directly invade the graft and restore the pink colour of the skin.

Related Pearl: Skin graft : phases of uptake of the graft

The take of skin graft occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): during the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation, in which cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses
  3. Neovascularization, in which blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft

Sensibility returns to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, with light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition,revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced by postgraft day 7 with fibroblasts)

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient presents with complaints of diarrhea and abdominal pain that typically worsens after taking food. The patient reports that the pain is often associated with cramps and that he has lost weight over the past few weeks. He looks emaciated and abdominal examination reveals the presence of a bruit. Which of the following investigations is the gold standard for diagnosing the condition that this patient is likely to have?

choices.text: Contrast enhanced MRI of the abdomen

questions.solution:
Based on the clinical history, the patient is likely to be suffering from chronic intestinal ischemia due to mesenteric arterial occlusion, for which the gold standard investigation is Mesenteric angiography. 

 

Points in favour of Diagnosis:

  • Complaints of abdominal pain that typically worsens postprandial (as there is an increasing need for blood flow to the intestine following meals): Intestinal angina
  • Cramps associated with the Pain
  • Presence of diarrhea
  • History of loss of weight
  • Emaciated appearance
  • Examination showing a bruit.  

Angioplasty with endovascular stenting is the treatment with an 80% long-term success rate.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient came to the hospital with complaints of right-sided loin pain. Urinary microscopy is shown in the image. Which of the following is used in the treatment of this renal calculi?
questions.solution:
Urinary microscopy of the patient shows hexagonal crystal suggestive of cystine stones. D-penicillamine can be used for treating cystine stones.

The basis of using D-penicillamine here is that it reacts with cysteine to form a soluble salt that reduces the formation of cystine.

It is a potentially toxic drug and should only be used if hydration and alkalinisation fail.

Other options:

Option A: Acetohydroxamic acid is used for the treatment of struvite stone. It is a urease inhibitor (urease enzyme generates ammonia from urea, elevating the pH of the urine and favoring the production of triple phosphate stones), can be used for oral chemolysis and can potentiate the action of antibiotics.

Option B: Neutral orthophosphates halt the growth of existing oxalate calculi.

Option C: Allopurinol, a xanthine oxidase inhibitor can be used to decrease uric acid production. Hence can be used in the treatment of uric acid renal calculi.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

  • Cystine stones: Hexagonal
  • Uric acid stones: Varying shapes (rhomboids or parallelograms)
  • Calcium oxalate
    • Monohydrate: Dumbbell shaped
    • Dihydrate: Octahedral or envelope shaped
  • Struvite stones: Rectangular or coffin lid

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with a rapidly enlarging neck swelling in the midline, along with hoarseness of voice and difficulty in breathing. H&E stained slide of the sample tissue is shown in the given picture. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a rapidly enlarging neck swelling, along with hoarseness of voice and difficulty in breathing and the image showing sheets of undifferentiated, anaplastic cells with marked cytologic atypia, are highly suggestive of Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma.

Undifferentiated or Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is a rare and one of the most aggressive malignancies in humans.

Anaplastic growths are usually hard, irregular, and infiltrating. It is characterised by rapid growth, visceral invasion, and distant metastases with a high mortality rate. Most patients die within 6 months of diagnosis.

 Radiotherapy and chemotherapy have not been shown to improve survival.

questions.text: A 48-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with the c/o non-cyclical mastalgia, which often radiates to the neck or shoulders. There is an area of localized tenderness on the left side of the chest wall, but no lump is palpable on examination. The pain subsides on taking NSAIDs . The condition she is suffering from is________.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario given above is suggestive of Tietze syndrome. It is a benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages and an extra-mammary cause of chest wall pain.

This commonly presents in postmenopausal women who are not taking HRT, as non-cyclical mastalgia, and the pain often radiates to the neck and shoulders. Treatment can be done with non-steroidal analgesics or by injection with a local anesthetic on a ‘trigger spot’.

 

Other options: 

Option A: Mondor’s disease is thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall. The pathognomonic feature is a thrombosed subcutaneous cord which is usually attached to the skin.

Option B: Zuska’s disease, also called recurrent periductal mastitis, is a condition of recurrent retro areolar infections and abscesses. Smoking has been implicated as a risk factor for this condition.

Option D: Paget's disease of the nipple is a superficial manifestation of underlying breast carcinoma. It presents as an eczema-like condition of the nipple

questions.text: Identify the disease shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image shown below is ectopia vesicae.

Also known as bladder exstrophy, it occurs in 1 in 50000 births with male: female ratio of 4:1.

In males, the penis is broad and short, and bilateral inguinal hernia may be present. There is separation of the pubic bones. In epispadias alone, the pubes are united and external genitalia are almost normal, although in females the clitoris is bifid.

Treatment:

  • The bladder is closed in the first year of life, usually after osteotomy of both iliac bones just lateral to the sacroiliac joints. Later, reconstruction of the bladder neck and sphincters is required.
  • In some patients the reconstructed bladder remains small and requires augmentation.

Less satisfactorily, urinary diversion can be carried out by means of ureterosigmoid anastomosis, an ileal or colonic conduit, or continent urinary diversion.

Long-term complications include:

  • Stricture at the site of anastomosis with bilateral hydronephrosis and infection
  • Hyperchloremic acidosis
  • An increased (20-fold) risk of tumour formation (adenoma and adenocarcinoma) at the site of a ureterocolic anastomosis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about the given image?

choices.text: Forms due to increase in the level of growth factors

questions.solution:
The given image shows a keloid scar. The histology of keloid scars shows excess collagen with hypervascularity, and there is more type 3 collagen.

Keloid scars are associated with elevated levels of growth factor.

A keloid scar is defined as excessive scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the original incision or wound. Its etiology is unknown, but is associated with elevated levels of growth factor, deeply pigmented skin, and inherited tendency and certain areas of the body (triangle whose points are the xiphisternum and each shoulder tip).

Keloid scars do not improve spontaneously with time and excision of the keloid scar has a high rate of recurrence.

Treatment:

  • Pressure - local moulds or elastic garments.
  • Silicone gel sheeting.
  • Intralesional triamcinolone injection
  • Excision and steroid injections
  • Excision and postoperative radiation (external beam or brachytherapy)
  • Intralesional excision.
  • Laser to reduce redness
  • Vitamin E and palm oil massage

questions.text: The oncosurgeon performed the incision as shown in the image. Identify the correct statement with respect to this incision.

choices.text: This  incison is done for dacryocystorhinostomy procedure
The incision is called Crile's incision
It is also done during modified radical neck dissection
It is used to access the floor of the maxillary sinus

questions.solution: The image shows Weber–Ferguson incision which is used to access the floor of the maxillary sinus in the case of maxillary carcinoma.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the instrument shown below?

choices.text: It is the safest in procedures close to vital structures
It can be used for coagulation
It can be used for cutting
There is more thermal dissipation of current

questions.solution:
The given instrument is a unipolar cautery. There is more thermal dissipation of current in unipolar cautery compared to bipolar cautery and it can cause damage to nerves and other vital structures.

In the monopolar electrosurgical procedure, a pencil-like probe is used. In the bipolar electrosurgical procedure, the bipolar device is used (often a set of forceps).

Related Pearl: Diathermy/Cautery

Features Monopolar Bipolar
Flow of current

Cautery pencil –> tissue –> cautery pad –> machine/ground

Hence more chance of burns

Only between tips of the instrument

Hence less chance of burns
Modes

Cutting – Low voltage, high amplitude, continuous waveforms

Coagulation – Alternate waveforms (Bursts)

Dessication – Low power

Fulguration – High power

 Only coagulation
Dissipation

More thermal dissipation of current

Hence can cause damage to nerves and other vital structures

Less lateral dissipation of current

Hence safer in procedures closer to vital structures

questions.text: Perforation of oesophagus is managed surgically in all cases except:
questions.solution:
Instrumental perforations in the cervical oesophagus are usually small and can nearly always are managed conservatively.

Indications for surgical exploration in Esophageal perforation-

  • Large septic load
  • Septic shock
  • Pleura breached
  • Boerhaave’s syndrome
  • Perforation of abdominal esophagus

Indications for considering non operative management in Esophageal perforation-

  • Small septic load
  • Minimal cardiovascular upset
  • Confined to mediastinum
  • By flexible endoscope
  • Cervical esophagus

Other options:

Option B:  Boerhaave’s syndrome requires urgent surgical repair due to its large, full-thickness tear and high risk of severe mediastinitis. Conservative management is insufficient for this life-threatening condition.

Option C: Perforation of abdominal oesophagus - Surgical intervention is necessary to repair the perforation and prevent peritonitis. 

Option D: Septic shock indicates severe systemic infection requiring immediate surgical source control. Conservative management alone is inadequate in this critical condition.

questions.text: False statement regarding pancreatic pseudocyst:

choices.text: CT is the investigation of choice
High amylase levels associated with high carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels

questions.solution:
Characteristic features of pancreatic pseudocysts include high amylase levels associated with the absence of mucin and low carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels.

High levels of CEA is suggestive of mucinous neoplasm.

  • The capsule of a pseudocyst is composed of collagen and granulation tissue, and it is not lined by epithelium.
  • It presents with abdominal pain and epigastric mass.
  • CT is the investigation of choice in pancreatic pseudocyst.

questions.text: Bipedicle flap is used in reconstruction of
questions.solution:
Bipedicle flap is a 'bucket-handle' flap supplied from both ends. It is very useful to rebuild the lower eylid.

High yield points:

A bipedicle flap is used for the eyelid whereas a bilobed flap is used for the nose.

questions.text: Ransohoff sign is seen in _________
questions.solution:
Yellow discoloration of the umbilical region is known as Ransohoff sign. It is seen in ruptured common bile duct.

Other abdominal examination signs:

 

Sign Explanation Diagnosis

questions.text:
The complications associated with refeeding syndrome are:
  1. Hyperkalemia
  2. Hypomagnesemia
  3. Hypercalcemia
  4. Hypophosphatemia
questions.solution:
Hypomagnesemia and hypophosphatemia, both occur in refeeding syndrome.

1 and 3 are false as, hypokalemia and hypocalcemia (NOT hyper), are complications of refeeding syndrome.

Refeeding syndrome is a fatal condition that can occur with rapid and excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition which may be due to:

  • Starvation
  • Alcoholism
  • Delayed nutritional support
  • Anorexia nervosa
  • Massive weight loss in obese patients

It can occur with either enteral or parenteral nutrition, but is more common with the latter.

With excessive refeeding, there is a shift in metabolism from fat to carbohydrate substrate which stimulates excessive insulin release. As a result, there is an increase in the cellular uptake of electrolytes, particularly phosphate, magnesium, potassium, and calcium.

Hence the metabolic abnormalities include:

  • Hypophosphatemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypocalcemia

These electrolyte disorders can result in myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, respiratory dysfunction, liver dysfunction, seizures, confusion, coma, tetany, and death.

Prevention and treatment:

  • Correct underlying electrolyte and volume deficits.
  • Additionally, thiamine should be administered before the initiation of feeding. Caloric replenition should be instituted slowly and should gradually increase over the first week.
  • Vital signs, fluid balance, and electrolytes should be closely monitored and any deficits corrected as they evolve.

questions.text: All of the following are true about sliding inguinal hernia except?

choices.text: It occurs at the deep ring medial to the inferior epigastric vessels
Sigmoid colon may be pulled in the the hernia on the left side
Extra caution during repair is needed to prevent injury to the bowel

questions.solution:
Sliding inguinal hernia occurs at the deep ring lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels.

Sliding inguinal hernia:

  • It is an acquired hernia due to weakening of the abdominal wall.
  • This occurs at the deep inguinal ring lateral to the Inferior Epigastric vessels.
  • Retroperitoneal fatty tissue is pushed downwards along the inguinal canal.
  • As more tissue enters the hernia, peritoneum is pulled with it, thus creating a sac.
  • However, the sac has formed secondarily distinguishing it from a classic indirect hernia.

Sigmoid colon can be involved on the left side and the caecum or bladder on the right side.

Surgeons need extra caution during repair as the wall of the large bowel may not be covered by peritoneum and can be damaged.

questions.text: All of the following are correct statements about carotid body tumor except

choices.text: It is seen in people who live at high altitude
10% patients have a positive family history
Carotid angiogram shows splaying of the carotid bifurcation

questions.solution:
Carotid body tumors/ chemodectoma are not hormonally active and the tumors are usually benign.

Carotid body tumour:

  • It occurs in people who live at high altitude
  • Occur in the 5th decade,10% have family history
  • Slowly growing tumour.
  • Carotid angiogram shows Lyre sign (splaying of the carotid bifurcation)
  • MRI angiography shows splaying of internal and external carotid arteries (Lyre’s sign).

questions.text: Deep inguinal ring is a defect in
questions.solution:
• Deep inguinal ring is a defect in fascia transversalis.
  • This ring lies midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic tubercle, approximately 2.5 cm above the inguinal ligament.
  • It lies lateral to inferior epigastric vessels.

questions.text: Partial posterior fundoplication for GERD is called:
questions.solution:
Partial posterior fundoplication is Toupet’s fundoplication.

questions.text: Hematemesis and melena are the usual presenting features of bleeding located _________
questions.solution:
Hematemesis and melena are the usual presenting features of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. Upper GI bleeding is derived from a source proximal to the ligament of Treitz.

The ligament of Treitz is part of the duodenojejunal junction and forms the line of demarcation for gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding.

Upper GI bleeding refers to bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz, and lower GI bleeding refers to bleeding distal to the ligament of Treitz.

questions.text: Conley’s pointer is related to ________
questions.solution:
• Conley’s pointer is one of the anatomical landmark for identification of facial nerve.
  • It refers to the inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal.
  • Facial nerve lies 1 cm deep and inferior to it.

questions.text: Grade II lymphedema is __________.

choices.text: Pitting edema up to the knees

questions.solution:
Grade II lymphedema is non-Pitting edema up to ankle.

Grading of Edema (Brunner)

Subclinical (latent) - No clinically apparent lymphoedema (excess interstitial ﬂuid and histological abnormalities in lymphatics and lymph nodes)

I -- Edema pits on pressure and swelling largely or completely disappears on elevation and bed rest

II -- Edema does not pit and does not signiﬁcantly reduce upon elevation, positive Stemmer’s sign

III -- Edema is associated with irreversible skin changes, i.e. ﬁbrosis, papillae

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Revised Trauma Score ?
questions.solution:
Pulse rate is not a component of Revised Trauma Score.

Glasgow coma scale, Respiratory rate and Systolic BP are components of Revised Trauma Score (0-12).

Various scoring systems are used to score the trauma are :

  • AIS – Abbreviated Injury Scale
  • ISS – Injury Severity Score
  • OIS – Organ Injury Scale
  • GCS – Glasgow Coma Scale
  • RTS – Revised Trauma Score
  • MESS – Mangled Extremity Severity Score
  • TRISS – Trauma and Injury Severity Score

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 1 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
1-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical

  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

  • Injury Severity Score
  • Revised Trauma Score
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)
  • Age

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with cancer risk?
questions.solution:
Schatzki’s ring is not associated with cancer risk.

Schatzki’s ring is a thin submucosal ring encircling lumen of the esophagus, usually situated at the squamocolumnar junction. It is associated with Hiatal hernia and gastroesophageal reflux. Schatzki ring is one of the most common causes of intermittent food impaction. Also known as "steakhouse syndrome" because meat is a typical instigator.

The best form of treatment of a symptomatic Schatzki’s ring in patients who do not have reflux consists of esophageal dilation for relief of the obstructive symptoms. In patients with a ring who have proven reflux and a mechanically defective sphincter, an antireflux procedure is necessary to obtain relief and avoid repeated dilation.

Eosophageal achalasia and zenker's diverticulum are linked with metaplasia and increased risk of cancer.

Pseudoachalasia is caused by an adenocarcinoma of the esophagus.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old woman presents with complaints of weakness for 2 months. She reports that she has been feeling weak, has difficulty rising from a chair, and combing her hair every morning. Physical exam reveals decreased strength in the shoulders and hip. On examination, the doctor noted that the patient had an erythematous rash over her eyelids, neck, and shoulder. She says that the rash is present for the past 1 year. Which of the following is true about this patient's condition?
  1. Associated with perimyseal infiltrates
  2. Associated with perivascular infiltrates with amyloid inclusion bodies and rimmed vacuoles
  3. Associated with CD4+ cellular infiltrates
  4. Generally resistant to immunosuppressive therapy
  5. Associated with underlying malignancy
questions.solution:
This patient with proximal muscle weakness along with erythematous rash over her eyelids (heliotrope rash), neck, and shoulders (V Sign, Shawl Sign) making dermatomyositis the most likely diagnosis. Dermatomyosistis involves CD 4+ cells, perimyseal infiltrates, and is associated with underlying malignancy.

Muscle biopsy findings in various inflammatory myositis are as follows-

Dermatomyositis Polymyositis Inclusion body myositis
Perimysial infiltrates Endomysial infiltrates  Endomysial infiltrates 
Perivascular infiltrates and perifascicular atrophy. Perivascular infiltrates    Perivascular infiltrates with amyloid inclusion bodies and rimmed vacuoles
CD4+ cellular infiltrates  CD8+ cellular infiltrates   CD8+ cellular infiltrates  

Dermatomyositis:

Dermatomyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy characterized by proximal skeletal muscle weakness, muscle inflammation, and a variety of characteristic skin manifestations. 

The pattern of muscle involvement helps distinguish a myopathy from a cerebral, spinal cord, neuronal or neuromuscular junction cause. 

It affects females more than males and has no familial association. It is generally associated with an underlying malignancy.

In dermatomyositis, skeletal muscle weakness involves proximal muscles symmetrically and on biopsy shows peri-fascicular atrophy.

A highly raised Creatinine kinase points towards a diagnosis as well.

Classic signs-

  • Heliotrope rash/ eyelid erythema- Violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids
  • V sign- Confluent macular erythema over the lower anterior neck and upper anterior chest
  • Shawl sign- Confluent macular erythema over the upper back and lateral aspect of arms
  • Gottron’s papules- Erythematous papules and plaques over extensor surface of the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints
  • Gottron's sign- Erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles. 
  • Mechanic’s hands- Rough, hyperkeratotic lines on the lateral and palmer areas of the fingers
  • Scalp erythema and hair loss
  • Facial rash- Confluent erythema in the malar distribution involving the cheeks, nasal bridge, and nasolabial folds
  • Nail fold changes
  • Flagellate erythema- Linear erythema on the upper back with pruritus
  • Poikiloderma- Mottled pattern of hyperpigmented and hypopigmented macules with telangiectasias
  • Cutaneous calcinosis- Accumulation of calcium deposits in the skin.

Dermatomyositis is generally responsive to immunotherapy. The general prognosis is good in patients without underlying malignancy. Poor prognostic factors include advanced age, associated interstitial lung disease/cardiac involvement and late onset of treatment.

Asymmetric muscle weakness with familial involvement is seen in inclusion body myositis. It is more common in males than females. There is early involvement of distal muscles like flexors of the fingers, wrists, and extensors of the knees. The response is generally poor to immunotherapies.

Note: Inclusion Body myositis is resistant to immunosuppressive medication 

 

Image below: Ragged cuticle and periungueal erythema in a patient with dermatomyositis.

The below image shows Shawl sign

The below image shows Gottron sign

The below image shows a heliotrope rash

Related Pearl: Inflammatory myopathy

Dermatomyositis Polymyositis Inclusion body myositis 
Age of onset
Adulthood and childhood >18 years >50 years
Familial association
No No Yes
Skin manifestation   
Yes No No
Muscle involvement 
Symmetric Symmetric  Asymmetric
Association with connective tissue disease   
Scleroderma and mixed connective tissue only Yes Yes
Association with autoimmune disease   
Infrequent Frequent Infrequent
Association with Malignancy   
Yes (most common- ovarian malignancy) Yes (incidence much lesser than dermatomyositis) No

questions.text: The following skin lesion is caused by ___________

choices.text: Hypersensitivity to Herpes Simplex virus infection

questions.solution:
The image shows numerous concentric rings indicative of Tinea imbricata, resulting from infection by Trichophyton concentricum.

  • The lesion presents as a scaling ring; centrifugal spread follows, but within the area of central clearing a second wave of scaling soon arises. The process is repeated to give numerous concentric rings .
  • Pruritus is intense and may lead to lichenification.
  • Hypopigmentation may accompany the lesions.
  • It is restricted to the natives of southern Asia, the islands of the South Pacific,Guatemala, southern Mexico and Brazil.

questions.text: Berloque dermatitis is caused due to _____
questions.solution:
• Berloque dermatitis is a type of skin pigmentation due to an acute phototoxic reaction to perfumes applied to the skin.
  • Berloque dermatitis results from the potentiation of UV-stimulated melanogenesis by 5-methoxypsoralen (bergapten) in perfumes containing bergamot oil.
  • Deep-brown pigmentation follows the pattern formed by the trickle of the droplets of perfume over the skin from their points of application.

questions.text: A young girl comes to the opd with complaints of nodules on her hair shafts as seen in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows irregular white nodules along the hair shafts suggestive of white piedra.

Piedra is a superficial fungal infection of the hair shaft. It is of two types:

  • White piedra: It is characterized by the presence of soft, white or light brown transparent nodules that are easily detached from the hair. It affects pubic, axillary, facial hair more commonly than scalp hair. It is caused by Trichosporon beigelii.
  • Black piedra: It is characterized by the presence of firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft. It affects the scalp hair most often. It is caused by Piedraia hortae.

It is usually asymptomatic. Management involves cutting off the affected hair and usage of topical antifungals.

 

Tinea capitis is the ringworm of the scalp. It leads to alopecia and scarring of the affected area. The image below shows tinea capitis:

 

Tinea nigra is a localized fungal infection of the stratum corneum, especially affecting the palms. It produces brownish/blackish macular lesions. It is caused by Exophiala werneckii. The given image shows tinea nigra:

questions.text: Which of the following are correctly matched?
questions.solution:
• Asteatotic dermatitis is also called Winter eczema.
  • Cradle cap and Dandruff are types of seborrheic dermatitis.
  • Bindi dermatitis is a type of allergic contact dermatitis.
  • Halo dermatitis is the occurrence of an eczematous ring surrounding a melanocytic nevus. It is also called Meyerson nevus or Meyerson phenomenon.
  • Vesicular dermatitis or Pompholyx is a form of eczema of the palms and soles in which edema fluid accumulates to form visible vesicles or bullae.

Dermatitis or Eczema is a reaction pattern caused by inflammation of the epidermis that typically manifests as scaling or crusting of the skin.

It is classified based on the etiology into Exogenous and Endogenous eczemas.

Condition Examples/ Synonyms Description
Exogenous eczemas: external factors predispose to eczema    
Allergic contact dermatitis Nickel dermatitis, Bindi dermatitis Delayed type of hypersensitivity reaction to a previously sensitized allergen
Irritant contact dermatitis Wear and tear dermatitis, Housewives eczema Cutaneous response to the physical/toxic effects of a range of environmental exposures.
Endogenous eczemas: Internal constitutional factors predispose to eczema      
Asteatotic dermatitis Winter eczema/Eczéma craquelé ‘Crazy paving’ pattern on legs due to dry skin, flares in winter
Atopic dermatitis Eczema infantum, eczema flexurarum, Hay fever eczema, asthmatic eczema Itchy, chronic relapsing condition that often starts in early childhood (<2 years) with erythema, papules/ papulovesicles, excoriation and lichenification in flexural distribution
Nummular dermatitis  Discoid eczema Circular or oval plaques of eczema with a clearly demarcated edge
Seborrheic dermatitis
  • Dandruff/ Sebo-psoriasis/ Pityriasis capitis/ Pityrosporal dermatitis
  • Cradle cap 
 Erythematous patches with superficial scaling, affecting areas with a high density of sebaceous glands- scalp, face, central chest, and anogenital areas

Cradle cap – seborrheic dermatitis

Bindi dermatitis- allergic contact dermatitis

Vesicular dermatitis - Pompholyx

questions.text: A 39-year-old obese ,non-diabetic, non-hypertensive female presented with grade 2 fatty liver with hepatic fibrosis and inflammation. She has no history of smoking or drinking. A diagnosis of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) has been made. Which of the following drugs can be used as the first-line treatment in this scenario?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, Alpha tocopherol or vitamin E is the first line treatment considered for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) for non-diabetic patients.

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is associated with diabetes and obesity. The fatty change may also be caused due to the effect of toxins (including certain medication), protein malnutrition, dyslipidemia, and anoxia. Bleomycin, Methotrexate, Doxycycline, l-Asparaginase are other drugs causing hepatic steatosis.

Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) is characterized by hepatic steatosis which is complicated by histologically evident hepatocyte death and inflammation. Currently, biopsy is the best investigation to establish the diagnosis.

The current approach to NAFLD management focuses on treatment to avoid or decrease the risk factors for NASH (like obesity, insulin resistance, metabolic syndrome, and dyslipidemia).

Alpha tocopherol or vitamin E is the first line treatment considered for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). In many studies, vitamin E was well-tolerated, showed modest improvements in AST levels, radiographic features of hepatic steatosis, and/or histologic features of NASH.

  • Vitamin E should only be considered as the first-line pharmacotherapy for non-diabetic NASH patients.
  • Dose: 800 IU/day.

 Other options : 

N acetyl cysteine(NAC) is a specific antidote for paracetamol poisoning. It has maximum efficacy when given within 8 hours and can be given either via oral or intravenous route.

Ursodeoxycholic acid (a bile acid that improves certain cholestatic liver diseases) and omega-3 fatty acids show no histologic benefit in the management of NASH.

Metformin is not currently recommended as a treatment for NASH as it has not been known to improve liver histology.

questions.text: You are evaluating a patient with metabolic syndrome. Presence of which of the following additional symptom in this patient constitutes a component of Syndrome Z?
questions.solution:
Syndrome Z is defined as a combination of obstructive sleep apnea syndrome with metabolic syndrome. 

Metabolic syndrome is diagnosed based on The NCEP: ATPIII Criteria. Three or more of the following must be present :

  • Central obesity: Waist circumference >102 cm (M), >88 cm (F)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia: Triglyceride level ≥150 mg/dL or specific medication
  • Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dL and <50 mg/dL for men and women, respectively, or specific medication
  • Hypertension: Blood pressure ≥130 mmHg systolic or ≥85 mmHg diastolic or specific medication
  • Fasting plasma glucose level ≥100 mg/dL or specific medication or previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes

questions.text: A 26-year-old male with a history of  respiratory tract infection 4 weeks ago is unable to stand or walk for the past 2 weeks and the weakness is progressive, ascending and symmetrical in nature. On examination you note areflexia and the speech is slurred. Which of the following would you administer him as the initial therapy?
questions.solution:
High-dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) is the initial therapy chosen for the treatment of Guillain Barre syndrome (GBS) which is given in the scenario above.

Treatment should be initiated as soon as diagnosis is made.

GBS is an acute, fulminant polyradiculoneuropathy that is autoimmune in nature. GBS is caused when immune response/antibodies against external antigens like infections, vaccines, etc target similar proteins present in the person's nervous tissue. Hence the preferred treatment is to neutralize these autoantibodies using IVIg (I.V. immunoglobulins) or plasmapheresis.

GBS manifests as a rapidly evolving areflexic motor paralysis with or without sensory disturbance. Respiration is compromised when it involves respiratory muscles. In such cases, ventilatory support is needed.

High-dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis are equally effective for typical GBS. IVIg is the initial therapy chosen because of
its ease of administration and good safety record. IVIg is administered as five daily infusions for a total dose of 2 g/kg body weight. GBS autoantibodies are neutralized by anti-idiotypic antibodies present in IVIg preparations.

IVIg is also preferred over plasma exchange (PE) for the AMAN and MFS variants of GBS.

Note: Steroid therapy is used in Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy.

questions.text: A morbidly obese diabetic and hypertensive woman failed metformin therapy with HbA1C levels- 9.2. Her past and family history are not significant  and she is willing to lose weight and compliant to treatment. Which of the following drugs would be suitable to reduce her glucose levels as well as weight?
questions.solution:
Liraglutide causes weight loss and improves glycemic control.

Also, it reduces the risk of cardiovascular death. It is better than exenatide in reducing HbA1C.

It is a soluble fatty acid-acylated GLP-1 analog. The half-life is approximately 12 hours, permitting once-daily dosing. It is approved in patients with type 2 diabetes who achieve inadequate control with diet and exercise and are receiving concurrent treatment with metformin, sulfonylureas, or thiazolidinediones.

It reduces post-meal hyperglycemia by

  • Increasing glucose-mediated insulin release
  • Lowering glucagon levels
  • Slowing gastric emptying
  • Decreasing appetite

It is used in type 2 DM and is the only GLP-1 receptor agonist used in obesity.

GLP-1 agonists should not be prescribed in patients with a family or personal history of medullary thyroid cancer or multiple endocrine neoplasia.

Other options:

DPP-4 inhibitors and alpha-glucosidase inhibitors are weight neutral drugs.

Sulfonylureas and insulin promote weight gain.

questions.text: A patient with chronic lymphocytic leukemia was started on fludarabine. 36 hours after starting the therapy, she developed abdominal pain, hematuria, vomiting, weakness, and paralysis. The laboratory investigations reveal hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia. Which of the following would you no longer recommend in the management of this condition?

choices.text: Aggressive hydration with normal or 1/2 normal saline

questions.solution:
The diagnosis is Tumour lysis syndrome where Hyperkalemia, Acidosis, Hyperuricemia, and Hyperphosphatemia can be seen along with Hypocalcemia. Urinary alkalization with sodium bicarbonate is no longer recommended in the management of this condition.

Urinary alkalization with sodium bicarbonate increases uric acid solubility, but a high pH decreases the solubility of xanthine, hypoxanthine, and calcium phosphate, and increases the likelihood of intratubular crystallization.

Tumour lysis syndrome is a recognized cause of AKI in patients with cancers. AKI occurs due to uric acid nephropathy and nephrocalcinosis (due to high serum calcium products). It most commonly occurs after the initiation of chemotherapy. Metabolic abnormalities in tumour lysis syndrome are hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia caused due to the destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating neoplastic cells. Acidosis and acute renal failure may also develop.

During chemotherapy, the treatment kills the malignant cells which lead to increased serum uric acid levels from the turnover of nucleic acids causing Hyperuricemia. This massive destruction of malignant cells may lead to hyperkalemia. Tumour lysis results in the release of intracellular phosphate pools, which causes hyperphosphatemia, this leads to reciprocal depression of serum calcium(hypocalcemia). Deposition of calcium phosphate and hyperphosphatemia leads to renal failure.

 Management of TLS includes:

  • Aggressive hydration
  • Allopurinol
  • Rasburicase - recombinant urate oxidase.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male student with cystic fibrosis developed acute onset cough which was worsening progressively, along with wheezing and increased sputum production. A probable diagnosis of of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) has been made. Which of the following is the incorrect option regarding the serological diagnosis for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) in a patient with cystic fibrosis. ABPA is diagnosed serologically, based on the detection of aspergillum-specific IgE or positive skin prick test and serum IgE > 1000 IU/ml. IgG antibodies to Aspergillus flavus are seen in chronic aspergillus sinusitis.

Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis:

ABPA is an eosinophilic pulmonary disorder caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to the colonisation of airways by the fungus Aspergillus fumigatus. It occurs almost exclusively in patients with asthma (~2.5% of patients) or cystic fibrosis (up to 15%). In chronic cases, repeated episodes of bronchial obstruction, inflammation, and mucoid impaction can lead to bronchiectasis, fibrosis and respiratory compromise.

With the development of ABPA, asthma or CF typically worsens and may manifest with a new or worsening cough or an increase in sputum production or wheezing. Many patients report coughing up thick sputum casts.

The presence of hyperattenuated mucus in airways is highly specific. While central bronchiectasis is characteristic, some patients can develop chronic cavitary lesions.

ABPA is diagnosed serologically, based on the presence of:

  • Serum IgE > 1000 IU/ml.
  • Positive skin prick test in response to A.fumigatus extract.
  • Detection of Aspergillus-specific antibodies.
  • Eosinophilia >500 cells/μL.

questions.text: A 20-year-old basketball player collapses during a match and regains consciousness several minutes later. He has had similar fainting episodes with occasional dyspnea before and his brother passed away at 25 during a soccer game due to a heart ailment.Echocardiography shows left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction and systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve leaflet. Which of the following is not a risk factor for sudden death in this patient?

choices.text: History of spontaneous sustained ventricular tachycardia

questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests a possible diagnosis of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). LV thickness >30 mm is a risk factor for sudden death.

Risk Factors for Sudden Death in Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy:

  • History of cardiac arrest or spontaneous sustained ventricular tachycardia (>3 beats at rate >120 Exercise)
  • Syncope (nonvagal,  with or after exertion)
  • Family history of sudden cardiac death
  • Spontaneous nonsustained ventricular tachycardia
  • LV thickness >30 mm (present in <10% of patients)- seen on Echocardiography
  • Abnormal blood pressure response to exercise

HCM is characterized by predominant diastolic dysfunction presenting as exercise intolerance. The patients have a dynamic left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction due to septal hypertrophy and systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve leaflet (SAM). SAM leads to mitral regurgitation with the jet directed posteriorly.

 

Related Pearl: One-liners on Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)

  • Diastolic dysfunction
  • Autosomal dominant
  • Most common mutation: Beta-chain of myosin
  • Missense mutation
  • Subaortic hypertrophy and stenosis
  • Systolic function normal
  • Banana shaped left ventricle
  • Asymmetric septal hypertrophy
  • Systolic anterior motion of left leaflet on Echocardiography
  • Myofibre disarray on histology

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency in a drowsy state. You check the vitals of this patient and send an ABG. The Lab values are as follows: pH=7.2 PCO2=30 mmHg HCO3= 7 mEq/L Cl= 111 mEq/L Na= 135 mEq/L

What is the acid-base disorder in this patient?

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap with compensatory respiratory alkalosis
Metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap with respiratory acidosis
Metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap with compensatory respiratory alkalosis
Metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap with respiratory acidosis

questions.solution:
This patient is suffering from metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap with respiratory acidosis.

Diagnosis can be arrived at by the following steps:

Step 1: A pH of 7.20 indicates acidosis. Normal pH is 7.35-7.45

Step 2: Bicarbonate level of 7 mEq/L( normal = 22-28)  together with low pH indicates that acidosis is due to loss of bicarbonate(i.e. base).Hence this is metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: Assessing the anion gap:

AG=( Na+)- {(Cl-)+(HCO3-)}

=135-(111+7)

=17 mEq/L

Normal anion gap is 8-12 mEq/L

Hence anion gap is increased.

Step 4: Assessing the compensatory response:

In metabolic acidosis, an appropriate respiratory compensation is to decrease PCO2, by excretion of volatile acid by hyperventilation. Expected PCO2 is calculated by the Winters formula:

PCO2=  [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2

= [1.5 X 7] + 8 ± 2

=16.5-20.5mm Hg

Since PCO2 is 30 Hg, it signifies inappropriate retention of CO2 indicating a respiratory acidosis in addition to a metabolic acidosis.

Anion gap

Normally, in the serum, the total number of cations is equal to the total number of anions. But, few of the anions (lactate, phosphate, and sulphate) cannot be measured and this is called an anion gap.

Anion gap = [Na+] −([Cl-]+[HCO3-])

Metabolic acidosis

Metabolic acidosis is of two types:

(1) Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA)

  • Diarrhea (Loss of bicarbonate is compensated by chloride reabsorption)
  • Renal tubular acidosis
  • Urinary tract diversions (reabsorption of ammonium and hydrogen by the bowel)

(2) High anion-gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA)

  • Lactic acidosis (hypoxia, malignancy)
  • Ketoacidosis (diabetic, starvation)
  • Poisoning (ethylene glycol, methanol, salicylate)

Related Pearl: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis

High Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (MUDPILES) Normal Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (FUSED CAR)
Methanol Fistula pancreatic
Uremia (Renal failure - Acute or Chronic) Ureterosigmoidostomy
Diabetic ketoacidosis Small bowel fistula
Paraldehyde Extra chloride (Hyperalimentation)
Iron tablets, INH Diarrhea
Lactic acidosis Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (acetazolamide)
Ethylene glycol Addison's disease
Salicylates Renal tubular acidosis

 

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 8 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic male presented with arthralgia and skin pigmentation. On examination, he was found to have hepatomegaly, arthropathy involving small joints, excessive skin pigmentation with characteristic slate-grey hue, and hypogonadism. What will be the best treatment for this disease?
questions.solution:
Phlebotomy is the best treatment for iron-overload states like hemochromatosis which is given in the clinical scenario above. One 500-mL unit of blood contains 200–250 mg of iron. Iron removal can be accomplished by weekly or twice-weekly phlebotomy of 500 mL.

With repeated phlebotomy, the following changes occur:

  • Liver decreases in size
  • Liver function improves
  • Hepatic fibrosis may decrease, but established cirrhosis is irreversible
  • Pigmentation of skin decreases
  • Cardiac failure may be reversed
  • Diabetes also improves in about 40% of patients.
  • There is little or no effect of arthropathy and hypogonadism. In some cases, arthropathy may even progress, despite therapy.

The goal is to reduce the serum ferritin levels to 50 - 100 ng/mL. Once the goal is reached, the phlebotomies may be done at appropriate intervals (usually, 3-4 times a year), required to maintain the serum ferritin levels at that level. 

Hemochromatosis is an autosomal recessive disease caused due to mutation in the HFE gene on chromosome 6. It is tightly linked to the HLA-A locus on chromosome 6p.

Pathogenesis:

The HFE protein is thought to play an important role in the process by which duodenal crypt cells sense body iron stores, leading in turn to increased iron absorption from the duodenum. A decrease in the synthesis or expression of hepcidin, the principal iron regulatory hormone, is also a key pathogenic factor. This excessively absorbed iron is primarily deposited in parenchymal organs such as the liver, pancreas and also heart, joints and endocrine organs.

Other features:

  • Hemochromatosis can also be acquired from iron overload due to hemolytic anaemia and transfusions.
  • It is associated with increased risk of Hepatocellular carcinoma.
  • Dilated Cardiomyopathy (DCM) is the most common manifestation of hemochromatosis. Hemochromatosis can also produce Restrictive cardiomyopathy but it is less common as compared to DCM. 

Other options:

Deferoxamine is used when phlebotomy is not well-tolerated. It is a chelating agent which removes 10–20 mg of iron per day when given parenterally.

Trientine and D penicillamine are chelating agents that bind to copper, and are used in the treatment of Wilson's disease.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of watery diarrhea, dehydration, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria. Which of the following neuroendocrine tumors can be responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of VIPoma.

Vasoactive intestinal peptide-secreting tumors (VIPomas) are neuroendocrine tumors that secrete excessive amounts of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP). The condition is known as Verner–Morrison syndrome or WDHA syndrome.

WDHA stands for:

  • WD - Watery Diarrhea
  • H – Hypokalemia
  • A – Achlorhydria

Diagnosis can be made by the demonstration of an elevated plasma VIP level and the history of large-volume diarrhoea.

Treatment includes correction of dehydration, hypokalemia, and electrolyte losses with fluid and electrolyte replacement. Long-acting somatostatin analogues such as octreotide and lanreotide are the drug of choice.

 

 

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Syndrome

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms
  • Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.
  • In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy with complaints of daydreaming in the class was brought by his teacher.Examination revealed that the child had episodes of sudden brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control, which were induced by hyperventilation.  Such episodes lasted for a few seconds with no post-ictal confusion. The child is most likely suffering from:
questions.solution:
Sudden, brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control and no post-ictal confusion is seen in Absence seizures. Usually, the seizure lasts only a few seconds.

The seizures may occur about 100 times a day, and the child is unaware. The seizures are so subtle, that may go unrecognized by parents. Most common complaints include "daydreaming" and a decline in school performance recognized by a teacher. The seizures can be provoked by hyperventilation.

EEG shows generalized symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern. Hyperventilation provokes these EEG discharges and seizures.

 

 

Other options:

  • Syncope is defined as transient, self-limited loss of consciousness due to a sudden decrease in cerebral blood flow. There is loss of postural control, and patients may faint.
  • Myoclonic seizures have preserved consciousness. They involve a sudden brief jerking movement involving the entire body or a part of it.
  • Atonic seizures are characterized by a sudden loss of postural control.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man underwent coronary artery bypass graft and has been in the hospital for the past 3 days. The patient is acutely confused with a temperature of 102°F and oxygen saturation of 91%. Blood test reveals raised inflammatory marker and chest X-ray shows a new right-sided infiltrate. Which of the following is the next best step in the diagnosis and/or management of this patient?

choices.text: Perform needle decompression and start antibiotics
Start treatment as per the local antibiotic policy for hospital acquired pneumonia after sending appropriate cultures
Perform  CT pulmonary angiogram to rule out pulmonary embolism
Immediately take the patient to theatre

questions.solution:
The clinical findings and radiological presentation are suggestive of pneumonia. Also, the patient has been in the hospital for > 2 days. The priority, in this case, is to start antibiotics for hospital-acquired pneumonia after sending appropriate cultures.

Pneumonia is defined as the presence of new lung infiltrates along with clinical evidence of its infectious origin, which manifests with fever, purulent sputum, leucocytosis, and a decrease in oxygen saturation.

Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or nosocomial pneumonia is a lower respiratory infection that presents clinically 2 or more days after hospitalization and was not there at the time of admission.

  • Early-onset HAP (occurring within 4-5 days) is most commonly caused by S. aureus, P. aeruginosa, Enterobacter species, K pneumoniae, and Escherichia coli
  • Late-onset HAP (> 5 days) is usually caused by Gram-negative bacteria (ex: Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Klebsiella spp, and Acinetobacter baumannii), S. aureus, and anaerobes.

Management:

  • The mainstay of management includes adequate oxygenation, appropriate fluid balance and antibiotics. The choice of antibiotics is most appropriately guided by knowledge of local patterns of microbiology and antibiotic resistance.
  • Co-amoxiclav or cefuroxime are the preferred agents in early HAP. If the patient has recently received antibiotics, then piperacillin/tazobactam or a third-generation cephalosporin should be considered.
  • In late HAP, an anti-pseudomonal cover may be provided by meropenem, cephalosporin or piperacillin-tazobactam. MRSA cover may be given by glycopeptides such as vancomycin or linezolid. A baumannii is usually sensitive to carbapenem but may require colistin in resistant cases.

questions.text: A 52-year-old diabetic male while undergoing hemodialysis, had a sudden drop in blood pressure and complained of leg cramps. Which of the following is the next best step in the management?

choices.text: Stop hemodialysis and check arterial blood gases
Discontinue ultrafiltration and start saline infusion
Continue hemodialysis and send blood for serum electrolytes
Check serum K+ and arterial blood gases

questions.solution:
The next best step in the management is to discontinue ultrafiltration and start saline infusion.

The clinical features are suggestive of hypotension which is the most common acute complication of hemodialysis. The treatment includes the infusion of saline.

Hypotension occurs due to hypovolemia, caused by excessive removal of fluids. Hypotension can be prevented by careful evaluation of the dry weight and by ultrafiltration modeling, such that more fluid is removed at the beginning rather than the end of the dialysis session. Removal of excess fluid may also cause muscle cramps due to a decrease in muscle perfusion.

The management includes discontinuing ultrafiltration, the administration of 100–250 mL of isotonic saline, or administration of salt-poor albumin.

Related Pearl: Hemodialysis vs Peritoneal dialysis

  • Hypotension

  • Muscle cramps
  • Anaphylaxis reaction

Complications :

  • Peritonitis
  • Catheter-associated non-peritoneal infections
  • Weight gain
  • Metabolic disturbances
  • Residual uremia

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented with fever, cough, dyspnoea, arthralgia, and painful rash on the lower limbs suggestive of erythema nodosum. Chest X-ray is shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
X-ray showing bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, together with the presence of erythema nodosum, suggest the diagnosis of sarcoidosis.

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disorder of unknown aetiology that is characterised by the presence of non-caseating granulomas.

In acute cases, patients may typically present with Lofgren’s syndrome, consisting of arthritis, erythema nodosum (as shown below), uveitis, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, lethargy, and occasional fever. Patients may also present with insidious onset of cough, exertional breathlessness and radiographic infiltrates.

Investigations:

  • Lymphopenia and deranged liver function tests are usually seen.
  • Hypercalcaemia may be seen, due to increased synthesis of calcitriol – 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D, by alveolar macrophages. In some patients, there may be hypercalciuria, which can lead to nephrocalcinosis.
  • Pulmonary function test shows a restrictive lung disease, with impaired gas exchange.
  • Bronchoscopy shows typical 'cobblestone' appearance of the mucosa. Bronchial and transbronchial biopsies reveal non-caseating granulomas. An increased CD4:CD8 T-cell ratio may be seen in bronchoalveolar lavage.
  • Chest X-ray is useful for staging of sarcoidosis.
  • HRCT shows reticulonodular opacities that follow a perilymphatic distribution centred on bronchovascular bundles and the subpleural areas.

Diagnosis:

  • Presence of erythema nodosum with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on chest X-ray is sufficient to make the diagnosis of sarcoidosis. Tissue biopsy is not required.
  • A typical presentation with classical HRCT features may also indicate the diagnosis.
  • In all other cases, the diagnosis should be confirmed by histological examination of the involved organ.

questions.text: The insulin regimen of a diabetic patient is demonstrated in the image below. The X axis represents time of the day and the y axis represents the effect of insulin. The arrows indicate the time of administration of insulin. Identify the insulin preparations marked A, B and C respectively.
questions.solution:
In the given image, A represents glulisine, B represents regular insulin and C represents NPH.

In the insulin regimen elaborated above,

  • Insulin preparation A has duration of action between breakfast and lunch - 3-4 hours . This indicates it is a ultra short acting insulin preparation - aspart, glulisine or lispro.
  • Insulin preparation B has a duration of action slightly longer than preparation A indicating it is a short acting insulin preparation - regular insulin
  • Insulin preparation C is administered twice in a 24-hour period indicating it is an intermediate acting preparation - NPH or lente.

Glargine, detemir and degludec are long acting insulin preparations mostly having once daily administration.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female presents with complaints of fatigue and severe itching throughout her body. Liver enzymes are elevated with normal bilirubin levels. The histopathological image of her liver biopsy is given below. Which of the following antibodies is most likely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Antibodies to Liver Kidney microsomes type 1

questions.solution:
The woman in the clinical scenario is suffering from primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC) and hence, she is most likely to have Anti Mitochondrial Antibodies (AMA).

She is said to suffer from PBC because of the following reasons

  • PBC has a strong female preponderance and the median age is around 50 years at the time of diagnosis
  • They present with fatigue and intense pruritus
  • Amond the liver enzymes, GGT and ALP are significantly elevated with only mild elevation of AST and ALT enzymes
  • 90% of the patients will have anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA)
  • Liver biopsy shows a florid duct lesion (as given in the image). This is due to the destruction of interlobular bile ducts with lymphoplasmacytic inflammation with or without granuloma formation.
