questions.text: Which of the following disease pathogenesis primarily involves the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in this transverse section of the brain is substantia nigra. Degeneration of substantia nigra is seen in Parkinson's disease, aka paralysis agitans.

Substantia nigra is pigmented due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which help in the synthesis of dopamine. In Parkinson's disease,  there is absence/reduced pigmentation of the substantia nigra.

Parkinson's disease:

  • Loss of the substantia nigra neurons projecting to striatum; the disease is primarily attributed to the decrease or absence of dopamine in the striatum
  • ↓ substantia nigra neurons = ↓ dopamine = ↓ movement ability
  • Bradykinesia, rigidity and resting tremor are classic features of Parkinson's disease.
  • Because of motor disability, it is also referred to as paralysis agitans.

Note: Depression is often a comorbid finding with Parkinson's disease, but is per se not due to damage to the substantia nigra.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male, presents to the ER with complaints of breathing difficulty and fever. RT PCR indicates he is COVID positive. Chest CT as shown below demonstrates ground-glass opacities close to the visceral pleural surfaces and visible intralobular lines. Which CO-RADS (COVID-19 Reporting and Data System) category does this patient fall under?
questions.solution:
As the patient has a positive COVID RT PCR, he would be classified as CORADS 6 - irrespective of his CT appearance.

 

CO-RADS Categories

CO-RADS 0 (Not interpretable - Technically insufficient to assign a score): Scans are incomplete or of inferior quality.

CO-RADS 1 (Very low risk - Normal/Non-infectious): Very low level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19. Mild or severe emphysema, perifissural nodules, lung tumors, or fibrosis.

CO-RADS 2 (Low - Typical for other infections but not COVID-19): Low level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19. Includes infectious etiology that is not compatible with COVID-19 such as bronchitis, bronchiolitis, bronchopneumonia, lobar pneumonia, abscess.

CO-RADS 3 (Equivocal - Features compatible with COVID-19, but also other diseases): Equivocal findings for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19. Findings overlap with other viral or infectious etiologies. Could include perihilar ground-glass, homogenous extensive ground-glass with or without sparing of secondary pulmonary lobules.

CO-RADS 4 (High - Suspicious for COVID-19): High level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19. Findings are similar to CO-RADS 5 but are not present in the typical locations. Findings may also be superimposed on severe pre-existing pulmonary abnormalities.

CO-RADS 5 (very high level of suspicion for pulmonary involvement by COVID-19) based on typical CT findings. It requires the presence of at least one confirmatory pattern - which includes ground glass regions, crazy paving pattern, and/or organizing pneumonia compatible patterns. Thickened vessels with parenchymal abnormalities is found in all confirmatory patterns

CO-RADS 6 (Proven): Proven COVID-19 by positive RT-PCR test.

questions.text: Polysomnography was done and the following breathing pattern was noticed. What is it called?
questions.solution:
The breathing pattern observed is called Cheyne-Stokes respiration.

Cheyne–Stokes respiration is characterized by progressively deeper and sometimes faster breathing, followed by a gradual decrease that results in a temporary stop in breathing called apnea.

Cheyne–Stokes respiration is present in 40% of patients with advanced HF and usually is associated with low cardiac output.

Cheyne–Stokes respiration is caused by an increased sensitivity of the respiratory center to arterial PCO2. There is an apneic phase, during which arterial PO2 falls and arterial PCO2 rises. These changes in the arterial blood gas content stimulate the respiratory center, resulting in hyperventilation and hypocapnia, followed by recurrence of apnea.

questions.text: A patient with abdominal pain underwent MRCP and findings are shown below, identify the correct match:

choices.text: Chronic pancreatitis with chain of lakes

questions.solution:
MRCP: Atrophic pancreas is seen, with irregular dilatation of pancreatic duct, and multiple intraductal calculi. This “chain of- lakes” appearance is diagnostic of chronic pancreatitis.

Acute pancreatitis is not associated with strictures and obstruction.

CT showing acute interstitial pancreatitis with diffuse swelling of the pancreas  and peripancreatic inflammatory changes (arrows). The pancreas was well perfused without evidence of necrosis. 

CT showing Acute pancreatic necrosis and edema of pancreatic tail and surrounding adipose tissue are visible (arrows).

questions.text: The following ECG  depicts ?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows right ventricular hypertrophy.

ECG findings suggestive of RVH:

  • R-V1 >= 7mm
  • R-V1 + S-V5/V6 > 11mm
  • Right axis deviation of +110° or more
  • T wave inversion in RV leads (Lead III, V1 & V2)

Causes of RVH

  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Mitral stenosis
  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Chronic lung disease (Cor pulmonale)
  • Congenital heart disease (e.g. Tetralogy of Fallot, pulmonary stenosis)
  • Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy

Other options:

1)The ECG depicts ventricular bigeminy seen in Premature Ventricular Complexes.

2)The ECG shows a right bundle branch block.

ECG findings suggestive of RBBB

  • RSR’ pattern in V1-3 (‘M-shaped’ QRS complex)
  • Wide, slurred S wave in the lateral leads (I, aVL, V5-6)
  • T wave inversion in the RV leads
  • Broad QRS > 120 ms

3)The ECG is of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) as it shows narrow QRS complexes without visible p waves and pseudo R' waves in aVR lead.

questions.text: Based on your observation of the foot of the patient shown below, what is the most likely diagnosis and its inheritance pattern?
questions.solution:
The given image shows periungual fibroma seen in tuberous sclerosis. Periungual fibromas are benign tumors that are composed of connective tissue and typically appear in the second decade of life or later.

Tuberous sclerosis is an inherited neurocutaneous disorder. It is inherited in autosomal dominant pattern.

The clinical features include:

  • Ash-leaf macules - hypopigmented macules -
  • Facial angiofibroma
  • Shagreen patches mostly over the lower back
  • Periungual fibromas

The image below shows an ash leaf macule.

The image below shows a Shagreen patch.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of the ECG given below?
questions.solution:
The ECG provided has characteristic J waves/Osborn waves diagnostic of Hypothermia.

Other options:

  • Hyperkalemia: Tall, tented T waves are seen in hyperkalemia.
  • Hypokalemia: U waves are seen in hypokalemia.
  • Hypocalcemia: Prolonged QTc interval, occasional T wave inversion.

questions.text: Breath sounds are decreased in all of the following except ________
questions.solution:
Tubular Breath sounds are heard over the region of consolidation in lobar pneumonia.

The following findings are seen in a consolidation:

  • Dull Percussion note
  • Tubular Breath sounds
  • Increased Vocal resonance
  • No Mediastinal shift
  • Added sounds- Midline Dull  Indux fine crackles or Redux coarse crackles

Note: Other options have decreased or absent breath sounds.

questions.text: In Type 2 diabetes mellitus, an increase in the fasting plasma glucose level is predominantly due to:
questions.solution:
In Type 2 diabetes mellitus, increased fasting plasma levels is predominantly due to increased hepatic glucose output

Whereas, increased postprandial plasma glucose level is due to decreased peripheral utilization of glucose.

questions.text:
Which of the following would be considered significant hematuria?
(HPF - High Power Field)
questions.solution:
The criteria for significant hematuria is RBC >100 in a single urinalysis

Hematuria is considered significant (or persistent) when:

  • RBC >3/HPF (high power field) on >3 occasions.
  • RBC >100 in single urinalysis
  • Gross hematuria.

questions.text: A diabetic nephropathy patient is an ideal candidate for renal graft transplant. Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: The survival rate of graft is 95% in the first year
The transplantation is cost effective after the second transplant year
The life expectancy is doubled in a diabetic patient with renal transplant
The treatment of chronic rejection has improved over the last 10 years

questions.solution:
Transplantation is cost-effective after 2 years in a patient with diabetic nephropathy. This statement holds true if there is no chronic rejection. The cost of transplantation is less compared to dialysis for two years.

Other options:

Graft survival in the first year is not 90%. It is around 82%.

The life expectancy is not doubled in a patient with diabetic nephropathy post-transplantation.

The term chronic allograft nephropathy (CAN) is used for chronic graft rejection in renal transplants. It mainly includes tubular atrophy, fibrous thickening of the arteries, fibrosis of the kidney interstitium, and glomerulosclerosis.

Risk factors that predispose a recipient to long-term graft rejection include HLA-mismatching, acute episodes of graft rejection, mismatch in donor-recipient age, and smoking. As chronic rejection is due to so many variables, the treatment is very difficult. Better treatment options are under research.

questions.text: Which part of the internal capsule is affected in hemiplegia due to ischaemic stroke?
questions.solution:
The posterior limb of the internal capsule is affected in hemiplegia due to ischaemic stroke.

Motor fibers (cortico-spinal tract) supplying the extremities are present in the posterior limb, hence a lesion in this region may cause hemiplegia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common antecedent infectious cause of Guillain-Barre syndrome?
questions.solution:
Campylobacter jejuni is one of the most common risk factors for GBS.

 Infections that may trigger GBS:

  • Campylobacter jejuni 
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
  • Epstein Barr virus
  • Mycoplasma
  • Varicella zoster virus
  • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), dengue, or influenza,Zika,hepatitis

Less commonly vaccinations, surgical procedures, and trauma have been reported to trigger the development of GBS.

questions.text: In a patient with NSTEMI, all the following can be used for treatment except?
questions.solution:
Streptokinase is not used in the management of NSTEMI. It is a fibrin nonspecific plasminogen activator used as a fibrinolytic agent in the treatment of STEMI.

Unlike STEMI, fibrinolytic therapy is not used in the management of NSTEMI. This is because STEMI is almost always caused by plaque rupture leading to the formation of an occluding thrombus, whereas, NSTEMI can be caused by a stable non-occluding plaque with some amount of lumen still patent. Fibrinolytic therapy may lead to the rupture of the stable plaque-causing more damage.

Acute coronary syndrome is commonly classified into:

  • Unstable angina
  • NSTEMI (Non-ST segment elevation MI)
  • STEMI (ST-segment elevation MI)

The treatment of NSTEMI is as follows:

  • Admission to a specialized cardiac unit
  • Inhaled oxygen
  • Bed rest with continuous ECG monitoring
  • Monitoring cardiac biomarkers
  • Nitrates
  • Beta-blockers
  • Antiplatelet drugs like aspirin, clopidogrel, prasugrel

questions.text: Resistant hypertension is defined as?

choices.text: BP >150/90 mmHg with one anti hypertensive
BP >140/90 mmHg with one anti hypertensive
BP >160/90 mmHg with three or more anti hypertensives
BP >140 /90 mmHg with three or more anti hypertensives

questions.solution:
Resistant hypertension is defined as blood pressure being persistently >140/90 mmHg despite taking three or more antihypertensive agents, including a diuretic.

Resistant hypertension is more common in patients aged >60 years than in younger patients. Resistant hypertension may be related to pseudohypertension (high office blood pressures and lower home blood pressures), nonadherence to therapy, and identifiable causes of hypertension including obesity and excessive alcohol intake.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is not seen in a patient with a Dextrocardia?

choices.text: Inverted P wave in lead I and lead aVL
Negative QRS comples in Lead I
Negative T wave in Lead I
Progressively increasing voltage across precordium in chest leads

questions.solution:
Progressively decreasing (not increasing) voltage across the precordium is seen in dextrocardia. This is because the heart is located on the right side, while the leads are placed on the left. Right-sided lead placement would show a normal progression.

Findings Suggestive of Dextrocardia

  • Inverted P waves in Lead I and aVL
  • Negative QRS complex and T wave in Lead I
    • (Lead I: inversion of all complexes, aka ‘global negativity’ i.e. inverted P wave, negative QRS, inverted T wave)
  • Progressively decreasing voltage across the precordium

 

ECG showing dextrocardia:

questions.text: The first hormone to be observed to fall in Sheehan’s syndrome is _______
questions.solution:
The order of hormone loss in Sheehan’s syndrome is GH → FSH/LH → TSH → ACTH.

GH deficiency is very common in Sheehan’s syndrome because somatotrophs are located in the lower and lateral regions of the pituitary gland, and are most likely to be damaged by ischemic necrosis of the pituitary.

Postpartum pituitary apoplexy is referred to as Sheehan’s syndrome. It is an endocrine emergency that may result in hypopituitarism, severe hypoglycemia, hypotension and shock, central nervous system (CNS) hemorrhage, and death.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male who is a known case of hypertension, presented with severe chest and back pain. CECT revealed an aortic dissection involving only the descending thoracic aorta, not extending into the abdominal aorta, distal to the left subclavian artery. According to the DeBakey's classification, the aortic dissection is classified as:
questions.solution:
The aortic dissection limited to the descending thoracic aorta is classified as DeBakey type IIIa.

questions.text: A peripherally inserted central catheter line(PICC) was placed in a patient to provide parenteral nutrition. Following the insertion, a chest X-ray was taken, which appeared as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the ideal position of the tip of this catheter?
questions.solution:
The ideal position of the tip of a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) line, is superior vena cava.

Peripherally inserted central catheters are commonly used for providing parenteral nutrition therapy. They are inserted through veins in the upper arm, and guided into the central venous system, such that the tip of the catheter enters the superior vena cava. A chest Xray is taken to confirm the position of the tip.

PICC lines have the advantage of minimizing inconvenience to the patients and clinicians. However, if the patient develops thrombophlebitis, the PICC line may be destroyed.

The image below shows (A) a typical PICC line (B) Illustration showing insertion of PICC line (C) A patient with PICC line inserted through the upper arm.

The image below shows the chest X-ray confirming the position of the tip of the PICC line (arrows), in the superior vena cava.

questions.text: A Barium swallow in an infant revealed the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The barium swallow is suggestive of double aortic arch.

The frontal chest radiograph shows two impressions on the barium-filled oesophagus, one impression on the right side due to the higher right-sided arch, and the other impression on the left-side due to the left-sided arch.

Double aortic arch is a congenital anomaly, characterized by the presence of persistence of both aortic arches, with the formation of a vascular ring. The right-sided aortic arch is usually higher and larger, while the normal left-sided aortic arch, is lower, and maybe hypoplastic or atretic.

Both the right and left arches, join the descending thoracic aorta after giving off the left subclavian artery.

The vascular ring may cause compression of the trachea and oesophagus. Depending on the degree of compression, the onset of symptoms may be in infancy, early childhood, or even adulthood.

Diagnosis is made on barium swallow, which shows compression of the oesophagus, on both the right and left sides.

questions.text: A cystic lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification is seen on the MRI. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A cystic lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification is suggestive of craniopharyngioma. It is derived from Rathke’s pouch and arises near the pituitary stalk, commonly extending into the suprasellar cistern.

Craniopharyngiomas are benign masses usually presenting the suprasellar region arising near the pituitary stalk and can produce functional impairment of the hypophysis due to mass effect. They can be clinically aggresive due to their tendency to recur. Adamantinomatous (children) and Papillary (adult) are two variants of craniopharyngioma. Calcification is characteristic of the adamantinomatous variety (found in childhood). Wet keratin nodules are the characteristic histologic feature of adamantinomatous type.

These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous, displaying both solid and cystic components, and occur within the suprasellar area. The cysts contain a cholesterol rich, thick brownish yellow fluid that is compared to "machine oil".

  • Patients usually come to attention due to a headache and visual changes including decreased acuity or visual field abnormalities (bitemporal hemianopia).
  • These children also have endocrinologic abnormalities such as growth failure and delayed sexual maturation due to pituitary hypofunction and GH deficiency. 
  • There can be evidence of mental retardation also. 
  • They are minimally invasive, adhere to adjacent brain parenchyma, and engulf normal brain structures
  • CT may show calcifications associated with the solid and cystic wall components.
  • MRI:
    • Cysts
      • T1: iso- to hyperintense to brain (due to high protein content "machinery oil cysts")
      • T2:Mostly hyperintense
    • Solid component
      • T1 C+ (Gd): vivid enhancement
      • T2: variable or mixed 

Usually treated by trans-sphenoidal or trans-cranial resection followed by adjuvant radiation therapy. 

Other options:

Option B: Pituitary adenomas are seen in the sellar region. Microadenomas are best shown on contrast-enhanced images. Marcoadenomas are seen as snowman or figure of eight appearance

Option C: Meningioma is a supratentorial tumor, mainly in the parasagittal region.

Option D: Oligodendroglioma is exclusively found in the cerebral hemispheres, most commonly in the frontal lobes.

questions.text: The following sign shown in the barium enema study is frequently seen in __________
questions.solution:
The sign shown in the barium enema study is the Apple core sign seen in Colonic cancer.

The apple core sign, also known as the napkin ring sign (bowel), is most frequently associated with constriction of the lumen of the colon by a stenosing annular colon carcinoma. 

The appearance of the apple-core lesion of the colon also can be caused by other diseases :

  • Villous adenoma
  • Lymphoma with colonic involvement
  • Crohn disease
  • Chronic ulcerative colitis
  • Ischaemic colitis
  • Chlamydia infection
  • Colonic tuberculosis
  • Helminthoma
  • Colonic amoebiasis
  • Colonic cytomegalovirus

questions.text: The clinical application of the effect shown below is -
questions.solution:
The Bragg peak effect is pronounced for protons. Proton therapy therefore allows to target tumors inside the body, precisely localize the radiation dosage and spare the patient’s healthy cells, offering a much less invasive alternative to treat cancer.

Protons and the Bragg peak effect:

The Bragg curve plots the energy loss of ionizing radiation during its travel through matter.

The proton is a heavy and charged particle that gradually loses its speed as it interacts with human tissue. It is easily controlled and delivers its maximum dose at a precise depth and can go as far as 32 cm. The proton is very fast when it enters the patient’s body and deposits only a small dose on its way. The absorbed dose increases very gradually with greater depth and lower speed, suddenly rising to a peak when the proton is ultimately stopped. This is known as the Bragg peak. The behavior of the proton can be precisely determined and the beam can be directed so the Bragg peak occurs exactly within the tumor site. Immediately after this burst of energy, the proton completely stops to irradiate and the particles come to rest. 

Proton therapy therefore allows to target tumors inside the body, precisely localize the radiation dosage and spare the patient’s healthy cells, offering a much less invasive alternative to treat cancer.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with a cardiac pacemaker is brought to the emergency room after he met with a road traffic accident. Which among the following investigations is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
MRI is contraindicated in this patient.

Ferromagnetic objects when near to a magnet experience a force of attraction towards the magnet bore and fatalities have occurred because of this. Most cardiac pacemakers and intracranial aneurysm clips contraindicate entry to the MR room.

MRI is contraindicated in:

  • Cardiac pacemakers
  • Metallic foreign body
  • Cochlear implant
  • Claustrophobia (relative contraindication)

questions.text: A 45 year old male having multiple sexual partners presents with the lesion in the anus. Biopsy reveals early stage of squamous cell carcinoma of anus. Correct management for for this patient is _____.
questions.solution:
Historically, treatment consisted of surgery alone or radiation therapy alone. Epithelial or subepithelial tumors were locally excised, and more advanced lesions underwent APR.

Nigro was the first to promote radiation therapy with chemotherapy as definitive treatment for squamous cell cancers of the anal canal.

Nigro regimen:

  • The current protocol includes infusional 5-FU with mitomycin C and external beam radiation to the pelvis with a minimum dose of 45 Gy.
  • The inguinal nodes, pelvis, anus, and perineum should be included in the radiation fields.
  • Patients with T2 lesions and residual disease after 45 Gy, T3 or T4 tumors, or node-positive disease are usually treated with an additional 9 to 14 Gy for a total dose of 54 to 59 Gy.
  • Patients with persistent disease up to 6 months after treatment generally require APR. Those who have local recurrence are also recommended for APR.
  • In the setting of isolated inguinal node recurrence, groin dissection is generally required with consideration for radiation therapy to the inguinal node basins if no prior radiotherapy was given.
  • In those patients presenting with anal squamous cell carcinoma in the setting of HIV infection, disease severity (CD4 count and use of antiretroviral therapy) has a significant impact on success of standard chemoradiation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Positron emission tomography - CT (PET-CT)?

choices.text: Enhanced whole body CT is followed by whole body PET imaging
It combines cross sectional anatomic information with metabolic information
Imaging is done after administration of oral glucose solution
Strenuous activity must be avoided prior to imaging

questions.solution:
Oral glucose solution is not given prior to PET-CET. Blood glucose should be < 150 mg/dL as FDG uptake is competitively inhibited by glucose. For this reason, the patient is asked to fast for 4-6 hrs prior to imaging.

Positron emission tomography - CT (PET-CT):

  • PET imaging is based on the detection of an injected positron-emitting radioactive tracer.
  • It relies on the coincidence detection of the annihilation photons (γ), which are released when a positron combines with an electron.
  • A glucose analogue called FDG (fluorodeoxyglucose) is used in PET imaging. FDG is taken up by metabolically active cells, where it undergoes phosphorylation to form FDG-6-phosphate. Unlike glucose, FDG-6-phosphate cannot undergo further metabolism and becomes trapped within the cell.
  • The trapped FDG-6-phosphate is detected by the PET scanner.
  • The combination of PET imaging with CT (PET-CT) combines the metabolic information (PET) with the cross-sectional anatomic information (CT).

Indications of PET-CT:

  • PET-CT is used in oncology imaging to detect malignant cells as they demonstrate increased glucose metabolism relative to normal tissues.
  • It is indicated for differentiation of a malignant from a benign lesion.
  • It is indicated in tumor staging and evaluation of tumor recurrence.

Technique:

  • The patient must be fasted for 4-6 hrs prior to imaging.
  • Strenuous activity must be avoided prior to imaging and after radioisotope injection to avoid physiological muscle FDG uptake.
  • Bladder catheterization or voiding prior to imaging, bowel opacification, or IV contrast medium are optional.
  • Before injecting FDG, the blood glucose level should be measured. It should be < 150 mg/dL. Good blood glucose control is essential as FDG uptake is competitively inhibited by glucose.
  • Imaging is started 60 minutes following FDG injection.
  • An enhanced whole-body CT study is done, which takes 60-70 seconds. Following which, a whole-body PET imaging, which takes about 30-45 minutes to complete.

questions.text: Personal monitoring of radiation is done by:
questions.solution:
Personal monitoring of radiation is done by TLD badge.

TLD badge (Thermoluminescent dosimeter) is made up of Lithium fluoride or dysprosium.

The badge should be positioned according to local or national practices, and the individuals are advised to wear badges at either the waist or the collar level or to wear them either under the lead apron or outside the lead apron.

questions.text: Recruitment is a feature of:
questions.solution:
Recruitment is a feature of cochlear hearing loss (e.g. Ménière’s disease and presbycusis). It refers to abnormal growth of loudness. Greater intensity sounds are heard louder than normal ear by abnormal ear.

It is tested by ABLB (Alternate Binaural Loudness Balance) test - A sound of 20 dB is heard in the defective ear at 60 dB but a sound of 90 dB is heard in the defective ear at 90 dB itself. In conductive hearing loss, a difference of 40 dB is maintained throughout.

Good ear: Ref/ reference ear and the poorer ear: Var /variable ear.

questions.text: Identify the instrument given in the following image.
questions.solution: The given image depicts Jansen’s self-retaining mastoid retractor used in mastoidectomy.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the OPD with 1-week history of toothache and 2 days history of neck swelling. He is diagnosed with Ludwig’s angina. How might you describe the swelling?

choices.text: Tender fluctuant swelling in floor of mouth
Tender fluctuant swelling in parotid region
Woody hard swelling in floor of mouth
Woody hard swelling in parotid region

questions.solution:
Ludwig's angina presents as woody hard swelling in the floor of mouth.

Clinical features:

  • Marked difficulty in swallowing (odynophagia) with varying degrees of trismus.
  • When infection is localized to the sublingual space, structures in the floor of the mouth are swollen and tongue seems to be pushed up and back.
  • When the infection spreads to submaxillary space, submental and submandibular regions become swollen, tender and impart woody-hard feel.
  • Usually, there is cellulitis of the tissues rather than frank abscess (on i&d show salted pork appearance)
  • The tongue is progressively pushed upwards and backward threatening the airway.
  • Laryngeal edema may appear

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution: The given image is that of an enucleation spoon. This is identified by the central cleavage that engages the optic nerve in enucleation.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions present with snow banking?
questions.solution: Pars planitis which occurs as a part of the intermediate uveitis presents with snow banking. It is due to the coalescence of snow like exudates at ora Serrata. Periphlebitis usually accompanies.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with bilateral proptosis, restriction of eye movements, and chemosis. Her thyroid profile showed she was euthyroid. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of thyroid ophthalmopathy.

Thyroid eye disease (TED) is the most common cause of both bilateral and unilateral proptosis in an adult in the euthyroid state. The main features of TED include lid retraction, proptosis, periorbital edema, chemosis, and restrictive myopathy.

Other options:

Option A- Orbital pseudotumor presents with painful eye movements periorbital edema, erythema, proptosis, ptosis, diplopia

Option C- Orbital lymphoma usually presents in the 7th decade, most commonly observed as a painless palpable mass in the superolateral quadrant.

Option D- Orbital cellulitis is usually U/L condition with pain, proptosis, and chemosis

Related Pearl: Signs in Grave’s ophthalmopathy

Sign Feature
Dalrymple's sign Retraction of the upper lids
von Graefe's sign Lid lag, i.e., when the globe is moved downward, the upper lid lags behind
Griffith Sign Lower lid lag on upward gaze
Enroth's sign Fullness of the eyelids
Stellwag's sign Infrequent blinking
Gifford's sign Difficulty in eversion of the upper lid
Mobius’ sign Convergence weakness
Joffroy’s sign Lack of wrinkling of the forehead on superior gaze
Jellinek's Sign Abnormal pigmentation of the upper lid

questions.text: A physician observed the following finding in a small child who came for an eye exam. This finding is seen in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Esotropia (convergent squint) is commonly seen in children with hyperopia (also known as hypermetropia).

It might result due to increased accommodative effort in cases where there is under correction of hypermetropia. The condition may be prevented by full hypermetropic correction.

If the child is unable to wear the glasses due to flat nasal bridge or if the child is less than 2 years old, the accommodation may be treated with drugs. Miotic drugs with anticholinesterase activity such as di-isopropyl fluorophosphate (DFP) or echothiophate can be used in these children. Further treatment may include orthotropic training or surgical correction of the squint.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with 6/6 vision in the right eye and vision for only hand movements in the left eye. On fundoscopy, the right eye appears normal. The left eye shows retinal detachment, subretinal yellowish exudates, and telangiectatic vessels. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of Coats' disease.

Coats' disease

  • Coats’ disease, described by Coats in 1908, affects boys three times more often than girls, has no reported racial or ethnic predilection, and is usually unilateral.
  • The average age at diagnosis is 8–16 years.
  • Ocular manifestations
    • Characterized by discrete zones of alteration in the retinal vascular structure with aneurysmal dilatation and leakage.
    • The typical ophthalmoscopic picture of Coats’ disease is one of retinal vascular abnormalities associated with localized lipid deposition (hard exudates) and varying degrees of subretinal exudates.
    • Vessels may appear telangiectatic, and they may have aneurysms that are grape-like, clustered, or light bulb shaped.
    • The clinical course is variable but generally progressive.
    • In children, Coats’ disease is typically diagnosed as a result of the recognition of poor vision, strabismus, or leukokoria.

Image: Coats’ disease. Note the typical vascular abnormalities with aneurysmal dilatation, telangiectasia, exudation, and severe lipid deposition in the macula.

questions.text: Which of the following nerve injury causes neurotrophic keratopathy?
questions.solution:
Neurotrophic keratopathy is due to loss of trigeminal nerve innervation resulting in partial or complete loss of sensation.

Causes:

  • Trigeminal ganglion surgical ablation for neuralgia
  • Stroke
  • Tumour
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Herpes simplex and herpes zoster keratitis (sectoral sensation loss)

Stages:

Stage 1: intrapalpebral epithelial irregularity, oedema and tiny focal deficits

Stage 2: Large persistent epithelial defects with rolled and thickened edges, assuming a punched out configuration

Stage 3: Stromal melting

Treatment: Topical lubricants, protection of the ocular surface with tarsorrhaphy, therapeutic silicone contact lenses, amniotic membrane patching.

 

Exposure keratopathy is caused by paralysis of the facial nerve.  

Exposure keratopathy

  • It is the result of incomplete lid closure (lagophthalmos), with the drying of the cornea despite normal tear production.
  • Causes 
    • Neuroparalytic, e.g., facial nerve palsy
    • Reduced muscle tone as in parkinsonism
    • Mechanical such as lid scarring
    • Proptosis

questions.text: A person travelling on flight experiences blockade sensation in his right ear, which then progressed to sharp pain during descent. Which of the following measures will prevent the occurrence of a similar episode in his next air travel?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms are suggestive of the middle ear barotrauma during flight descent. Using vasoconstrictor (oxymetazoline) nasal spray half an hour before descent can prevent this.

Otitic barotrauma is a non-suppurative condition resulting from the failure of the eustachian tube to maintain middle ear pressure at ambient atmospheric level. The usual cause is rapid descent during an air flight, underwater diving or compression in the pressure chamber.

Measures to prevent middle ear barotrauma:

  • Swallow repeatedly during descent (as swallowing opens up the eustachian tube and equalizes the middle ear pressure)
  • Avoid sleeping during descent as the number of swallows normally decrease during sleep
  • Auto inflation of the tube by Valsalva should be performed intermittently
  • Vasoconstrictor nasal spray/ antihistaminic and systemic decongestant tablet  half an hour before descent can effectively prevent this
  • Occlusive earplugs are contraindicated due to the risk of the external ear barotrauma

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the marked zone?

choices.text: This zone is an example of dysplasia
This zone does not take up the iodine in VILI test
The formation of this zone is influenced by progesterone
Nabothian cysts are seen in this zone

questions.solution:
The marked zone is the transformation zone. When the overgrowing new squamous epithelium as a result of metaplasia blocks the cervical crypts in the transformation zone, they turn into a mucus-filled small structure called the nabothian cyst.

Salient features of the transformation zone:

  • The area between the old and new squamocolumnar junction is called the transformation zone.
  • This stands as an example of metaplasia wherein, the columnar epithelium of the exposed endocervical canal is transformed into another type of mature epithelium (squamous epithelium).
  • Various hyperestrogenic states such as puberty, pregnancy, and OCP result in the exposure of the endocervical columnar epithelium beyond external os, thus augmenting the formation of the transition zone.
  • This zone acts as the central point in giving rise to various premalignant lesions due to the continuous cellular turnover that happens in this zone.
  • As this zone contains squamous epithelium with glycogen in it, they take up iodine when stained with Lugol’s iodine in VILI test.

questions.text: The common complications that you would expect to be associated with this abnormal placenta are all except
questions.solution:
Preterm labour is not a complication of placenta succenturiata.

The given image depicts placenta succenturiata in which one or more small lobes of placenta may be placed at a distance from main placental margin.

Its complications are -

  • Postpartum haemorrhage
  • Subinvolution
  • Uterine sepsis
  • Polyp formation

questions.text: The image depicts the quantitative test for fetomaternal haemorrhage. Which of the following is a correct conclusion?

choices.text: Fetal RBCs are washed out and maternal RBCs are Red
Maternal RBCs are washed out and fetal RBCs are Red
Both maternal and fetal RBCs are washed out and few immature RBCs are alone red
Both maternal and fetal RBCs are red and few immature RBCs are washed out

questions.solution:
The test shown is the Kleihauer-Betke test. Maternal RBCs are washed out and fetal RBCs are red is the correct conclusion. 

Kleihauer-Betke test

  • It is also called as acid elution test. 
  • Procedure
    • A blood smear is prepared from maternal blood and is exposed to acid bath.
    • If there is fetomaternal haemorrhage , then after staining the fetal erythrocytes appear red and adult cells appear as ghosts. This is because of resistance of fetal haemoglobin to acid elution.

Kirby-Bauer test is a disc diffusion test used for antibiotic sensitivity of bacteria

Etest - is used to determine minimum inhibitory concentration of drugs.

Rosette test - is a qualitative test used to identify whether fetal Rh D positive cells are present in the circulation of  Rh D negative mother.

questions.text: The method shown in the image is:
questions.solution:
The image shows marshall burns technique used in the delivery of aftercoming head in breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Baby is allowed to hang by its own weight till the nape of neck is visible
  • When the nape of neck is visible under the pubic arch, baby is grasped by the ankles
  • Baby is swung in an arc in an upward and forward direction towards the mother's abdomen

Other Options: 
Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.
Pinard’s maneuver used for delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.
Ritgen maneuver is used for controlled delivery of head in normal labor.

questions.text: Not true about the device shown in the image is:

choices.text: Green filter is used to study vascular pattern
External os is visualised at a distance of 50 cm

questions.solution:
The device shown is a colposcope and it is used to visualize the cervix at a distance of around 20 cm with a magnification of 6x-15x.

  • It provides binocular vision
  • The patient is put in the lithotomy position
  • The green filter can be used to study vascular pattern. The vessels will appear black.

questions.text: Identify the phase of menstruation given below:
questions.solution:
The image depicts proliferative phase of endometrium. 

Features in proliferative / oestrogenic phase

  • The glands of the functional layer are simple tubules with regular epithelium
  • Endometrium is thick, stoma compact, short straight glands are present.
  • Arteries become more coiled and spiralled

Features in Secretory phase 

  • The secretory phase of the endometrium begins on the 15th day and persists until the onset of menstruation.
  • Subnuclear vacuolation (presumptive evidence of progesterone activity)
  • Corkscrew-shaped glands

The image below shows secretory endometrium

Features in Menstrual Phase

  • Glands shrink with prominent vessels and haemorrhagic spots.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition in the image?

choices.text: Can be detected early by sonology

questions.solution:
The image is of a fetus compressus. It is more common in monozygotic twins.

In some pregnancies, one fetus dies remote from term, but pregnancy continues with one or more live fetuses. When this occurs early in pregnancy, it may manifest as a vanishing twin.

Fetal death in a slightly more advanced gestation may go undetected until delivery of a normal appearing live infant along with a dead fetus that is barely identifiable.

It may be compressed appreciably–fetus compressus, or it may be flattened remarkably through desiccation—fetus papyraceus.

questions.text: The following image depicts _______
questions.solution:
The above image depicts frank breech.

Breech presentation can be divided into the following:

  • Incomplete breech: Breech with extended legs, footling, knee presentation
  • Complete: Breech with flexed legs
Frank breech
(with extended legs)		 Footling Knee presentation Complete/flexed
Thighs flexed on the trunk, legs extended at the knee joint. Both thighs and legs are partially extended Thighs extended, Knee flexed Both thighs and legs are flexed.
Presenting part: Buttocks and genitalia Foot Knee Buttocks, genitalia, foot

questions.text: Anatomical classification of the pelvis based on shapes is given by ______.
questions.solution:
The Caldwell-Moloy anatomical classification of the pelvis is based on shape.

The greatest transverse diameter of the inlet and its division into the anterior and posterior segments are used to classify the pelvis as follows:

  • Gynecoid
  • Anthropoid
  • Android
  • Platypelloid

Note:

McAffee and Johnson regimen: Conservative management of placenta previa 

Page's and Sher's classification systems: Grading of abruptio placenta

questions.text: The characteristics of caput succedaneum include all of the following except _____.

choices.text: It does not disappear within 2-3 days.
It is a diffuse edematous swelling of the soft tissues of the scalp.

questions.solution:
Caput succedaneum disappears within 2-3 days.

In vertex presentations, labor forces alter the fetal head shape. In prolonged labors, before complete cervical dilatation, the portion of the fetal scalp immediately over the cervical os becomes edematous.

The formation of this swelling is due to the stagnation of fluid in the layers of the scalp beneath the girdle of contact.

The swelling is diffuse, boggy, and not limited by the suture lines. It resolves spontaneously within 2-3 days after birth.

It signifies the static position of the head for a long period of time.

questions.text: The weight of the fetus and placenta are equal at _______
questions.solution:
In the first trimester, the placental growth is more rapid than that of the fetus.

By approximately 17 post-menstrual weeks, the placental weight and fetal weight are almost equal.

By term, placental weight is approximately 1/6th of the fetal weight.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida at 20 weeks of gestation presents to the OG clinic for targeted sonography.  In the sonogram, a finding of single umbilical artery is noted. No other gross congenital anomalies detected.  Which of the following is true regarding the finding?

choices.text: An indicator of increased risk of malformations of the fetus
Equally common in newborns of diabetic and non-diabetic mothers

questions.solution:
Single umbilical artery is the most common aberration of vessel number in the umbilical cord. It is an indicator of increased incidence of congenital malformations in the fetus.  

It is more common in twins and in babies born of women with diabetes, epilepsy, oligohydramnios, hydramnios, pre-eclampsia, and antepartum hemorrhage.

It is frequently associated with congenital malformation of the fetus (20–25%), mainly cardiovascular and genitourinary. Renal and genital anomalies, trisomy 18 are common.

There is an increased chance of abortion, fetal aneuploidy, prematurity, intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), and increased perinatal mortality.

questions.text: A Pregnant lady delivered a full term male baby at term.  She started to bleed profusely soon after the delivery of the placenta.  On examination, uterus is flabby and becomes hard on massaging.  All of the following are risk factors for this condition, except______
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of atonic PPH. HELLP syndrome is not a known risk factor for atonic PPH.

HELLP causes PPH due to abnormal coagulation and not by atony.

Risk factors for Atonic PPH:

Parity:Primi/Grand multipara
Previous PPH
Overdistented uterus:multiple pregnancy, hydramnios, macrosomia
Precipitate labour, prolonged labour

Uterine malformations, fibroid uterus
Labor induction with prostaglandins or oxytocin

Placental anomalies:Placenta previa/accreta/increta/percreta/

                              Abruptio placenta

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with cystocele?
questions.solution:
• Stress incontinence is mostly experienced by women with cystocele and genital prolapse.
  • In this condition, the woman involuntarily voids a small amount of urine while laughing, sneezing, or coughing. There is no desire to pass urine.
  • This may also be seen during pregnancy or in the postpartum period.
  • Urge incontinence is a condition wherein a woman gets a sudden urge to pass urine, and if she does not get to a lavatory quickly, she passes a considerable amount of urine involuntarily.
  • True incontinence is the continuous leakage of urine seen in genital fistulae.

questions.text: Which of the following therapeutic agents is available as a nasal spray for leiomyomas?
questions.solution:
Nafarelin is available as a nasal spray for leiomyomas.

  • Leuprolide acetate (Lupron) is FDA-approved for leiomyoma treatment and is available in a 3.75-mg monthly dose or 11.25-mg 3-month dose, both given intramuscularly.
  • Less frequently used GnRH agonists include goserelin (Zoladex), administered as a 3.6-mg monthly or 10.8-mg 3-month subcutaneous depot implant; triptorelin (trelstar), given as a 3.75-mg monthly or 11.25-mg 3-month IM injection; and nafarelin (Synarel), used in a 200-μg twice-daily nasal spray regimen.
  • The latter three are not specifically FDA-approved for leiomyoma treatment, but their off-label use has been shown to be effective.

A new agent, elagolix sodium (Orilissa), is a nonpeptide oral GnRH antagonist that is recently approved by FDA for the management of moderate to severe pain associated with endometriosis.

questions.text: Corpus cancer syndrome constitutes ______.

choices.text: Hypertension, obesity, stroke, cancer of body of uterus
Stroke, DM, hypertension, cancer of body of uterus
DM, obesity, hypertension, cancer of body of uterus
Obesity, stroke, DM, cancer of body of uterus

questions.solution:
Corpus cancer syndrome: Diabetes mellitus, obesity, hypertension, cancer of the body of the uterus

Etiology of endometrial carcinoma:

(Mnemonic: Family Has OLD AUNTI)

  • Family: Family History
  • Has:Hypertension
  • O: Obesity
  • L: Late menopause/Early menarche
  • D: Diabetes
  • A: Atypical endometrial hyperplasia
  • U: Unopposed estrogen/increased estrogen → Hormone replacement therapy, fibroid, PCOD
  • N: Nulliparous
  • T: Tamoxifen therapy (Raloxifen has no genito-urinary action)
  • I: Infertility/irregular menses.

Genes: BRCA1, BRCA2, HNPCC

Protective factors:

  • Oral contraceptive pills
  • Smoking
  • Multiparity

questions.text: Which is the most common type of ovarian tumor?
questions.solution:
The most common type of ovarian tumor is epithelial tumor.

Classification of ovarian tumors:

1) Epithelial tumors (Most common)

  • Serous cystadenoma
  • Serous cystadenocarcinoma
  • Mucinous cystadenoma
  • Mucinous cystadenocarcinoma
  • Endometriod
  • Brenner tumor
  • Clear cell tumor
  • Undifferentiated

2) Germ cell tumors (Mnemonic: TEDY Chor)

  • Teratoma
  • Embryonal cell carcinoma
  • Dysgerminoma
  • Yolk sac tumor
  • Choriocarcinoma

3) Sex cord stromal tumors

  • Androgen-secreting tumors: Sertoli cell, Leydig, Hilus cell tumor
  • Estrogen-secreting tumors: Granulosa cell, Thecoma, Fibroma

4) Metastatic ovarian tumors

questions.text: Post-coital test was performed in a couple who presented with inability to conceive in spite of staying together for 4 years and having unprotected intercourse. This test can detect all of the following, except?
questions.solution:
The post-coital test is not useful to detect fallopian tube block.

Post-coital test (Sims’ or Huhner’s test):

  • The couple is advised intercourse close to the ovulation time, preferably in the early hours of the morning. The woman presents herself at the clinic within 2 h after the intercourse. The mucus is aspirated from the cervical canal and spread over a glass slide.
  • Another smear made from the posterior fornix serves as a control. Normally 10–50 motile sperms are seen per high-power field in cervical mucus.
  • The cervical mucus is simultaneously examined for its quantity, viscosity, and fern test.

The advantage of this test is that the cervical mucus can be simultaneously studied for oestrogenic effect and ovulation, its capability to allow sperm penetration, and presence of any anti-sperm antibodies. The test is useless in the presence of cervical infection, which should be treated before performing the post-coital test. Immunological factor is encountered in 5% cases.

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument is Kocher's artery forceps, identified by artery forceps with a single tooth.

Please note the difference between artery forceps and needle holders by the smoothness of corrugations (artery forceps have smooth edges; single lines), needle holder having rough edges (crossed lines) identified by square- to diamond-shaped corrugations.

Kocher's artery is non-traumatic and is used to achieve hemostasis by holding bleeding vessels.

questions.text: Examination of a patient with cervical carcinoma revealed a cervical lesion of 6 cm, extending to the upper part of the vagina and parametrium. What is the stage of the disease?
questions.solution:
The stage of cervical carcinoma is 2 B as it extends beyond the uterus, i.e., the upper part of the vagina and parametrium and the lesion is > 4 cm.

This question and the pearl is according to the recent guidelines by FIGO for cancer cervix.

Related Pearl: Staging of Ca.Cervix

Clinical staging of Ca.Cervix

Stage 1: Limited to the cervix( extension to the uterine corpus should be disregarded)

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1: Measured stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2: Measured stromal invasion 3-5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion ( lesion limited to cervix uteri)
    • B1: Invasive carcinoma ≥5mm in depth of stromal invasion, <2cm in greatest dimension
    • B2: Invasive carcinoma ≥2cm to <4cm in greatest dimension
    • B3: Invasive carcinoma ≥4cm in greatest dimension

Stage 2 

  • A: extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1: Invasive carcinoma <4cm in greatest dimension
    • A2: Invasive carcinoma ≥4cm in greatest dimension
  • B: extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage 3

  • A: extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: extends to the pelvic wall (Hydronephrosis/ non functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent. 

             C1: pelvic lymph node metastasis only.

             C2: para-aortic lymph node metastasis

Stage 4

  • A: Bladder + Bowel involvement
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note:

Most common stage of presentation: IIIB

Inguinal lymph node is involved very rarely in Ca. Cervix.

The involvement of vascular/ lymphatic spaces do not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

questions.text: The antenatal diagnosis of vasa previa can be done by _____.
questions.solution:
The antenatal diagnosis of vasa previa can be done by color Doppler.

Vasa previa:

  • The unsupported umbilical blood vessels in the velamentous placenta lie below the presenting part and run across the cervical os.
  • The vessels are torn either spontaneously or during rupture of membranes.
  • Color Doppler is helpful in antenatal diagnosis.
  • Fetal mortality is high (50%) due to fetal exsanguination.
  • Bleeding is fetal in origin and not maternal.

 

Image: Macroscopic image of the placenta with a velamentous insertion of the umbilical cord

questions.text: A pregnant lady with PIH was being monitored with bed rest in supine position. Which of the following is a complication of the below representation?
questions.solution:
Supine vena cava syndrome is the complication of the given representation.

The above image shows compression of the inferior vena cava by the gravid uterus, this compression sometimes leads to supine vena cava syndrome. During late pregnancy, the gravid uterus compresses the great vessels against the hard spine, when the patient is in the supine position. Of the two vessels, the vena cava is compressed, but the aorta is resistant to compression, owing to its structure. The vena caval compression normally, however, results in opening up collateral circulation by means of paravertebral and azygous veins. In some cases, when the collateral circulation fails to open up, the venous return of the heart may be seriously curtailed.

This results in hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope and is called supine vena cava syndrome. The normal blood pressure is quickly restored by turning the patient to the lateral position.

questions.text: A 33-week pregnant woman with pre-eclampsia presents with clinical features suggestive of HELLP syndrome. What is the best management approach?

choices.text: Give steroids and wait till 37 weeks
Give MgSo4 and deliver at 36 weeks

questions.solution:
The definitive management of PIH/eclampsia is termination of pregnancy only.

Indications for termination of pregnancy, irrespective of gestational age, in cases of pre-eclampsia are as follows:

  • Severe pre-eclampsia
  • Eclampsia (give MgSO4 followed by induction of labor)
  • HELLP syndrome
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Significant renal dysfunction, coagulopathy
  • Fetal compromise

Other options:

Option B: Give steroids and wait till 37 weeks: This would be the answer if it were mild pre-eclampsia. Here, it is a case of severe pre-eclampsia with HELLP syndrome.

Option C: Give MgSo4 and deliver at 36 weeks: MgSO4 is given for prophylaxis of eclampsia in patients with severe pre-eclampsia and pregnancy is terminated at >34 weeks. If 27-34 weeks, give corticosteroids and deliver after 24 hours of the last dose of steroid.

Management of severe pre-eclampsia is outlined in the following flow chart:

questions.text: A 34-year-old female came to the OG clinic with 6 weeks of amenorrhea. Her UPT is positive.  She is a known case of mitral stenosis for 5 years.  The best time to do surgery for mitral stenosis in this patient is _______
questions.solution:
The best time of surgery is between 14–18 weeks.

  • Mitral stenosis surgery (or any cardiac surgery in pregnancy) should usually be postponed until after delivery, but if required, it can be performed safely in the 2nd trimester.
  • Balloon valvuloplasty is the procedure of choice and the best time to do surgery during pregnancy is 14–18 weeks.
  • The normal mitral valve surface area is 4.0 cm2, and when stenosis narrows this to <2.5 cm2, symptoms usually develop.

questions.text: A 32-year-old G4P3 Rh negative female with antibody titre of 1:32 presents to the OG clinic at 30 weeks.  USG reveals features of hydrops fetalis and polyhydramnios.  Cordocentesis was performed to estimate fetal hematocrit.  Intrauterine transfusion is indicated if hematocrit is:
questions.solution:
Intrauterine transfusion is done if fetal haematocrit is <30%

More about intrauterine transfusion 

  • O negative blood group cross matched with mothers blood is used 
  • It is highly packed to achieve haematocrit of 75 -80%

Routes

  1. Intra Peritoneal :- Blood is absorbed through Diaphragmatic lymphatics 
  2. Intra vascular :- Intrahepatic portion of umbilical vein or umbilical vein at cord insertion into placenta is used
  3. Combined method of 1 and 2

questions.text: Benefits of transverse abdominal incision for cesarean are all except _____
questions.solution:
Transverse abdominal incisions offer a narrow operating space.

Related Pearl: Transverse and vertical incisions in Cesarean section

Transverse Incisions Vertical incisions

Advantages

  • Follows Langer lines of skin tension, so superior cosmetic results
  • Less Postoperative pain
  • Less fascial wound dehiscence
  • Low incidence of incisional hernias

Advantages

  • Quick entry
  • Minimal blood loss
  • Superior access to the upper
    abdomen
  • Wide operating space
  • Flexibility for easy wound extension if necessary

Disadvantages

  • High infection risks
  • Narrow operating space
  • Injury to neurovascular bundles
  • Reentry during repeat C-section is difficult due to scarring 

Disadvantages

  • Poor cosmetic results
  • Higher fascial dehiscence 
  • Higher incisional hernia rates
  • Greater postoperative pain

questions.text: Massive painless vaginal bleeding after a 6-8 week period of amenorrhoea, in a premenopausal woman, is suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Metropathia haemorrhaghica, a specialised form of anovulatory DUB, is seen in women aged 40 to 45 years.

Typical symptoms are continuous painless vaginal bleeding at the onset of menses, or preceeded by a 6-8 week period of amenorrhoea. Occasionally the woman gives a history of menorrhagia prior to this.

The uterus is slightly bulky, uniformly enlarged and the uterine wall shows a mild degree of myohyperplasia, measuring upto 2.5 cm. The endometrium is thick, polypoidal, and thin slender polyps project into the uterine cavity. The endometrium shows characteristic cystic glandular hyperplasia, which appears as a swiss cheese pattern. The second feature is the absence of secretory endometrium i.e absence of cork screw glands (as the bleeding is anovulatory, there is no progesterone and hence no secretory changes in the endometrium).

Corpus luteum is absent and one or both ovaries may contain a cyst, not larger than 5 cm.

questions.text: A couple presents to you after unprotected sexual intercourse and asks for an emergency contraceptive. All of the following are mechanisms by which emergency contraceptives act, except?

choices.text: Preventing the implantation of the fertilized egg

questions.solution:
Emergency contraception has no role in the interruption of early pregnancy, once conceived. They are not abortifacients.

Emergency contraceptives are used to prevent pregnancy, after unprotected intercourse. They are interceptives. Their main action is to make the endometrium unsuitable for implantation. They can also delay or inhibit ovulation, and prevent fertilization of the egg by sperms.

questions.text: A woman is diagnosed to be positive for HIV in her first trimester. What is the appropriate management?

choices.text: Start ART immediately and continue till 6 weeks after delivery.
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue life-long.
Start ART immediately and continue life-long.
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue till 6 weeks after delivery

questions.solution:
ART should be initiated in all pregnant and breastfeeding women living with HIV regardless of WHO clinical stage and at any CD4 cell count and continued lifelong.

Note: Under NACO, With effect from 1st January 2014, pregnant women who are found to be HIV positive are initiated on lifelong ART irrespective of CD4 count and WHO clinical Staging.

questions.text: Tests for ovarian reserve were done in an infertile female who has been planned for ovulation induction. Which of the following test is the best indicator for ovarian reserve?
questions.solution:
FSH is the best indicator of ovarian reserve among the given options.

Ovarian reserve means the capacity of the ovary to produce eggs.

High FSH means the ovarian reserve is getting depleted and fewer oocytes are remaining in the ovary (FSH is highest in postmenopausal women). FSH levels are higher than normal in women with reduced ovarian reserve and ovarian hypofunction. FSH levels are measured in the early follicular phase (Day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle)

Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) is a better marker than FSH for ovarian reserve and has the advantage that its levels can be estimated at any time of the cycle, unlike FSH. AMH is produced by the Granulosa cells in ovarian follicles (In males, it is produced by the Sertoli cells). AMH in females is always absent during embryogenesis.

LH/FSH ratio may be useful in certain clinical scenarios, such as diagnosing certain disorders or conditions affecting the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. However, it is not typically used as a primary marker for assessing ovarian reserve.

Studies show that AMH levels decrease under the current use of oral contraceptives and current tobacco smoking.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument used in Ilizarov ring fixator.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Kirschner wire (K-wire).

Kirschner wire or K-wire has multiple uses. Insertion is stress-free, associated with less soft tissue damage and allows for early exercises after removal. The diameter of the K-wire is 1 to 3 mm. The wire is pointed at both ends for both antegrade and retrograde insertion. The shape of the tips could be trocar or diamond or threaded.

Uses of K-wire are:

  • To fix fractures in children
  • To give traction e.g. for olecranon fracture
  • To fix small bone fractures
  • In llizarov ring fixator

Related Pearl: Orthopedic Instruments

questions.text: Which of the following bone tumours is radioresistant?
questions.solution:
Metastasis to bone are generally radiosensitive, except for Renal cell carcinoma which is conventionally regarded as radioresistant.

In patients aged more than 50 years, metastatic bone tumors are more common than primary bone tumors. It should be suspected in any lytic bone lesion. Osteoblastic lesions are uncommon and seen in prostate carcinoma. Primary tumors are most often found in breast, prostate, kidney, lung, thyroid, bladder and GIT. These metastasize to the vertebra, pelvis, femur and humerus.

It presents more often as only pain or may be discovered incidentally in a pathological fracture. Treatment is usually a combination of chemoradiation and surgery. Bauer's criteria define the prognosis, the more the score, the better the prognosis.

Related Pearl: Important radiosenstive and radioresistant bone tumours

  RADIOSENSITIVE

   RADIORESISTANT

Metastasis (except metastasis from renal cell carcinoma which are radioresistant)

Osteosarcoma

Ewing’s Sarcoma

Chondrosarcoma

Multiple myeloma

Fibrosarcoma

Lymphoma

Malignant fibrous histiocytoma

questions.text: A newborn was born with the deformity as shown in the image below. You apply a cast  as per Ponseti's technique and ask them to return for complete treatment. The patient is however lost to followup and returns only 2 years later when he joins the school. Which of the following will you do?
questions.solution:
The image shows congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV). Since the child is less than 3 years, soft tissue release procedures should be done as per the agewise management protocol of CTEV.

The first line management for CTEV is Ponseti's technique in which gradual correction of deformities are is done by plaster cast. The sequence of correction is given as:

C- Cavus 

A- Adduction

V- Varus

E- Equinus

Ponseti's method is the currently used method conservative management of CTEV and previously Kite's method was followed.

  Ponseti's method Kite's method
Treatment start <2 weeks 1 month
Order of correction cavus -adduction - varus- equinus adduction - inversion -equinus
Fulcrum  Head of talus Calcaneocuboid joint
POP type Above knee cast Below knee cast
Duration 6-8 weeks 6-9 months

In addition to the above procedure, we can provide the child with CTEV shoes as the child has started walking to retain the correction.

Features of CTEV shoes:

  • Straight inner border prevents adduction
  • Outer shoe raise prevents foot inversion
  • Absence of heel prevents equinus
  • Used once the deformity is corrected and when the child starts walking, upto 5 years of age

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

questions.text: Which of the following is matched correctly for bone involved in osteochondritis?

choices.text: Calve's disease - central vertebral body nucleus

questions.solution:
Amongst the given options, Calve's disease - Central vertebral body nucleus is correctly matched.

Osteochondritis

  • Refers to the detachment, necrosis, and softening of a small part of the bone and articular cartilage.
  • It affects children and adolescents during increased physical activity.
  • It may be triggered by stress, causing a small osteochondral/epiphysis fracture 
  • In early stages, it is detectable on MRI but missed on X-ray.
  • In later stages, a radiolucent line maybe visible on X-ray corresponding with the detachment of fractured segment.

Treatment 

  • Early stages involves load reduction and rest to allow for spontaneous healing
  • Later stages surgery may be done.

The different osteochondritis are given in the below pearl.

Related Pearl: Osteochondritis

Few important osteochondritis  
Osteochondritis Bones affected
Kienbock  Lunate
Scheuermann  Ring epiphysis of vertebra
Perthes  Proximal femoral   epiphysis

Sever  Calcaneum
Kohler  Navicular bone
Freiberg

Second

(or 3rd,4th,5th)metatarsal head

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department after he fell on his outstretched hand. An X-ray was performed and is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The  X-ray reveals an oblique fracture in the lower third of the radius and there is dislocation of the distal radio-ulnar joint, which is diagnostic of Galeazzi fracture-dislocation.

The patient with Galeazzi fracture-dislocation presents with pain, swelling and deformity at the lower end of the radius. On clinical examination, the disruption of the radio-ulnar joint can be elicited by pressing the lower end of the ulna. The ulna moves down and comes back like the key of a piano (piano-key sign). 

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar displacement.

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius.

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of the ulnar bone.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is diagnosed with amnesia. Which of the following will not be impaired in this patient?

choices.text: Name of pet bird growing up

questions.solution:
The ability to drive a bicycle will not be impaired in this patient with amnesia.

The ability to drive a bicycle is a non-declarative memory and non-declarative memory is preserved in amnesia.

Non-declarative memory includes:

  • Skill learning
  • Habit learning
  • Simple forms of conditioning

Declarative memory supports the conscious recollection of facts and events.

  • Memory for routes, lists, faces, melodies, objects
  • Memory for other verbal and nonverbal material

Memory of the melody of his favourite song, name of pet bird growing up and route navigation are all types of declarative memory.This is impaired in amnesia.

Related Pearl: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient complains of excessive daytime sleepiness and sleep attacks. Her daytime sleepiness began at the age of 13 and has been worsening. Eventually, at the age of 19, she developed episodes of a sudden loss of muscle tone, precipitated by strong emotions. Which of the following is most likely to be found associated in this disease?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of narcolepsy. Hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations can be seen in narcolepsy.

Narcolepsy is characterized by the tetrad of: 

  • Excessive daytime sleepiness
  • Cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone)
  • Hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations
  • Sleep paralysis

The hallmark of narcolepsy is decreased REM latency, i.e. decreased latent period before the first REM period occurs. Normal REM latency is 90-100 minutes. In narcolepsy, REM-sleep usually occurs within 10 minutes of the onset of sleep (Sleep onset REM).

Treatment: 

  • Sleep hygiene
  • Scheduled naps
  • Avoidance of alcohol and drugs that cause drowsiness
  • Drugs: 
    • Modafinil (wakefulness-promoting drug) is the drug of choice.
    • Amphetamines
    • Methylphenidate

Related Pearl: Events occurring in NREM and REM sleep

Events occurring during NREM stages 3 and 4:

Events

Description

Somnambulism

Sleepwalking

Sleep terror or Night terror

Also called Pavor nocturnus.

Awakens with a scream or intense anxiety. Has increased autonomic disturbances.

They do not have a memory of this when they wake up.

Runs in families and seen more frequently in childhood and boys.

Treatment with benzodiazepines is rarely required.

Nocturnal enuresis

Behavioral therapy is the mainstay.

Drugs like desmopressin and imipramine are used.

 

Events occurring in REM sleep:

Events

Description

Nightmares

Fearful sleep without autonomic disturbances that are well remembered in the morning.

TCAs may be used for treatment.

Nocturnal penile tumescence

A normal phenomenon that can be used to differentiate between psychogenic and organic impotence.

Narcolepsy

A disorder of the REM sleep characterized by disturbed sleep in the night, leading to excessive sleep in the morning.

Associated with symptoms such as cataplexy, hypnogogic and hypnopompic hallucination, and sleep paralysis.

 *Hypnogogic hallucinations are those that occur at the start of sleep and hypnopompic hallucinations are those that occur at the end of sleep.

 

Others:

Events

Description

Bruxism (teeth grinding)

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Frontal lobe epilepsy

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Sleep talking

Occurs in all stages of sleep and may accompany night terrors and sleepwalking.

Common in children.

No treatment is necessary.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents with poor appetite, anger, and sadness. She has had the symptom from the past 14 months ever since her husband died. She also complains of hearing her husband's voice at times. What is the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is suffering from persistent bereavement disorder

After the loss of a loved one, there is a grief reaction as in this patient.If the grief reaction extends for more than 12 months in bereaved adults or 6 months in bereaved children, it is called persistent bereavement disorder.  This reaction also occurs with other losses, such as loss of a body part, or, for younger people with a miscarriage or abortion.

Other options:

Option A: Dysthymia is defined as a low mood occurring for at least two years
Option B:The depressive features in this patient are not severe enough for a diagnosis of major depressive disorder
Option C: Normal grief in adults lasts for up to 1 year.

Note: The above information is according to DSM 5. 

Related Pearl: Normal vs abnormal grief

 Normal vs abnormal grief

Grief/bereavement

Pathological Grief/depression

Sadness, tearfulness, decreased sleep, decreased appetite, decreased interest in the world

Sadness, tearfulness, decreased sleep, decreased appetite, decreased interest in the world

Symptoms wax and wane

Symptoms pervasive and unremitting

Shame and guilt are less common

Shame and guilt are common

Threaten suicide less often

Threaten suicide more often

Symptoms can last up to 1 year

Symptoms continue for more than one year

Usually, return to baseline level of functioning within 2 months

Patients do not return to normal functioning

Treatment includes supportive psychotherapy

Treatment includes antidepressants

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents to the OPD with deprivation in sleep, elation, and talkativeness for 4 days. He also complains of irritability and distractibility. His social and occupational functioning has not been impaired. He has previously suffered from 3 episodes of major depression 1 year back. What is the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of type II bipolar disorder.

This patient's clinical features of decrease sleep, irritability,distractibility, elation, and talkativeness for 4 days without social and occupational impairment is suggestive that this is an episode of hypomania. Since the patient has had episodes of major depression in the past, the diagnosis is Bipolar II.

Types of Bipolar disorder:

  • Bipolar I: Episodes of mania with or without episodes of major depressive disorder (at least one-lifetime episode of mania is required for diagnosis).
  • Bipolar II: Episodes of hypomania with episodes of major depressive disorder (negative history of a manic episode is required for diagnosis).

Related Pearl: Bipolar disorder

Bipolar & related disorders

Manic episode

  • Symptoms more severe
  • 1 week unless hospitalized
  • Marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or hospitalization necessary
  • May have psychotic features; makes episode manic by definition

Hypomanic episode  

  • Symptoms less severe
  • 4 days to less than 7 days
  • Unequivocal, observable change in functioning from patient's baseline
  • Symptoms not severe enough to cause marked impairment or necessitate hospitalization
  • No psychotic features

Bipolar I

  • Manic episode(s)
  • Depressive episodes common (but not required for diagnosis)

Bipolar II

  • Hypomanic episode(s)
  • Major depressive episodes (required for diagnosis)

Cyclothymic disorder

  • At least 2 years of fluctuating, mild hypomanic & depressive symptoms that
    do not meet criteria for hypomanic episodes or major depressive episodes

questions.text: Schneider’s first-rank symptoms of schizophrenia include all of the following except ________
questions.solution:
Ambivalence is not a first-rank symptom of schizophrenia. It is one of the 4A’s of schizophrenia as described by Bleuler.

The first rank symptoms of schizophrenia described by Kurt Schneider include :

1. Hallucination:

  • Audible thoughts - auditory hallucinations of a person’s voice being spoken aloud.
  • Voices arguing or discussing - auditory hallucinations of two or more voices arguing or discussing, usually about the person experiencing the hallucination.
  • Voices commenting on the patient’s actions - auditory hallucinations commenting on a person’s behavior or actions.

2. Thought Phenomenon : 

  • Thought withdrawal -  thoughts being actively removed from a person’s mind.
  • Thought insertion - thoughts inserted into a person’s mind by some external agent.
  • Thought broadcasting - the sense that a person’s thoughts are experienced by others - the thoughts are made audible or may be experienced by others through telepathy.

3. Made Phenomenon:

  • Made affect - feelings are imposed on that person by an external agent.
  • Made impulses or drives - an impulse for action is imposed on a person by some external agent.
  • Made volitional acts - a person’s actions are controlled by an external agent; the person is a passive participant in the action.

4. Delusional perception - the person attaches an abnormal significance/meaning to a normal perception, which leads to delusional interpretation.

5. Somatic passivity - tactile or visceral hallucinations that are thought to be imposed on a person's body by some external agent.

These symptoms are not specific for schizophrenia and may also be present in other psychiatric disorders.

Related Pearl: Symptoms of schizophrenia

Positive symptoms Negative symptoms
Hallucination
Delusion
Bizarre motor acts
Flattening of affect
Anhedonia
Alogia
Apathy
Paucity of thought
Poverty of speech
Common in acute schizophrenia Common in chronic schizophrenia
Hyperactivity of the dopaminergic system in the mesolimbic system Hypoactivity of the dopaminergic system in the mesocortical system
Respond to most typical and atypical antipsychotics Respond better to atypical antipsychotics

questions.text: A junior resident was conducting a study on factors affecting dead space. In which of the following posture and airway position would he notice the maximum increase in dead space?
questions.solution:
A junior resident would notice a maximum increase in dead space in Upright posture with Neck extension.

Dead space is the volume of a breath that does not participate in gas exchange. It is ventilation without perfusion.

  • Total dead space (Physiological dead space) = Anatomical dead space+alveolar dead space.
  • Anatomical dead space is the area in the tracheobronchial tree where the gaseous exchange between the lung and capillaries doesn’t take place. It includes nasal cavity, larynx, trachea, bronchi, end of the terminal bronchiole.
  • Alveolar dead space is the volume of gas within unperfused alveoli (and thus not participating in gas exchange either)

Factors affecting dead space:

Decrease

Pulmonary embolism

Increase

Increase

Emphysema
