questions.text: A 35-year-old man who underwent surgery for appendicitis was given a high dose of opioids postoperatively to relieve the pain. But within few hours,  a fall in SpO2 and respiratory rate were noted. Which of the following drugs has been accepted as standard therapy in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of opioid-induced respiratory depression and Naloxone has been accepted as standard therapy in this patient.

Opioid-induced respiratory depression is mediated by the action on µ receptors (µ2) in the brainstem respiratory centers. Naloxone is an opioid antagonist, which can reverse the respiratory depression induced by opioids.

Respiratory depression can be prolonged when opioids are taken with other CNS depressant substances like alcohol, barbiturates, benzodiazepines, inhalational anesthetics, and other sedative-hypnotics.

However, droperidol, scopolamine, and clonidine do not enhance the respiratory depressant effects of fentanyl or other opioids.

Related Pearl: Pure opioid antagonists

Naloxone: A short-acting opioid antagonist with a duration of action of 1-2 hours. Used in opioid overdose and respiratory depression in newborn due to perinatal opioid use.

Naltrexone: A Long-acting opioid antagonist with a with effects lasting till 48 hours. Used for prevention of relapse in opioid addiction treatment. It is associated with hepatotoxicity. It does not suppress craving in opioid addiction but suppresses craving in chronic alcoholics.

Nalmefene: A Long-acting opioid antagonist with a half-life of 8-10 hours administered intravenously. Used in opioid overdose like naloxone.

questions.text: An intern while monitoring SpO2 of a patient using pulse oximetry records readings of SpO2 between 80% to 85% even with 100% oxygen. In which of the following conditions will the pulse oximetry reading be 80-85% irrespective of arterial oxygen saturation (SaO2)?
questions.solution:
In a patient with methemoglobinemia, the pulse oximetry reading will be 80% to 85% irrespective of arterial oxygen saturation(SaO2). Methemoglobin has the same absorption coefficient at both red and infrared wavelengths. The resulting 1:1 absorption ratio corresponds to a saturation reading of 80%-85%.

Pulse oximetry is a non-invasive measurement of the oxygen saturation of hemoglobin.

The relative absorption of light by oxyhemoglobin (HbO) and deoxyhemoglobin is assessed by measuring the amount of red and infrared light emerging from tissues traversed by light rays and processed by the device, producing an oxygen saturation level.

But, a pulse oximeter is not always reliable as it reads

  • 80% to 85%, irrespective of the arterial oxygen saturation - methemoglobinemia
  • Falsely high - carboxyhemoglobinemia 
  • Falsely low - severe anemia, low cardiac output states, hypovolemia, increased systemic vascular resistance.

Methemoglobinemia:

Methemoglobin is generated by oxidation of the heme iron moieties to the ferric state, causing a characteristic bluish-brown muddy color resembling cyanosis. Methemoglobin has such high oxygen affinity that virtually no oxygen is delivered. Levels >50–60% is often fatal.

  • Congenital methemoglobinemia arises from globin mutations that stabilize iron in the ferric state 
  • Acquired methemoglobinemia is caused by toxins that oxidize heme iron 
    • Chloroquine
    • Dapsone
    • Sulfonamides
    • Nitroglycerin

questions.text: An elderly male was taken up for surgery after induction with an intravenous anesthetic agent. During recovery from anesthesia, he started experiencing hallucinations and vivid dreams. Which of the following drugs is most effective in reducing the incidence and severity of these post-operative reactions?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of emergence reaction/delirium associated with Ketamine. Benzodiazepines are most effective in reducing the incidence and severity of these reactions.

Emergence reactions seen with ketamine include vivid dreaming, extracorporeal experiences (sense of floating out of the body), and illusions (misinterpretation of a real, external sensory experience) during emergence from anesthesia. These are usually associated with excitement, confusion, euphoria, and fear.

Larger doses and rapid administration of large doses seem to predispose patients to a frequent incidence of adverse effects.

Emergence reaction can be reduced by the use of benzodiazepines.

Ketamine:

Ketamine is an NMDA receptor antagonist which is used intravenously as an anesthetic and analgesic agent. It also causes neuronal hyperpolarization at the HCN1 channels.

questions.text: Incidence of post-dural puncture headache does not depend on the _______
questions.solution:
The timing of ambulation does not seem to affect the incidence of post-dural puncture headache, i.e., early ambulance does not increase the incidence.

Related Pearl: Factors That Can Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Age: Younger, more frequent
  • Sex: Females > males
  • Needle size: Larger > smaller
  • Needle bevel: Less when the needle bevel is placed in the long axis of the neuraxis Orienting a needle bevel parallel with the axis of the spine, such that the longitudinal fibers of the dura would more likely be separated than cut, results in a lower incidence of postspinal puncture headache
  • Pregnancy: More when pregnant
  • Dural punctures: More with multiple punctures

Factors That Do Not Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Insertion and use of catheters for continuous spinal anesthesia
  • Timing of ambulation

questions.text: During the routine ophthalmic examination of a 6-year- old child as a part of a school health survey, you notice the following finding as shown in the image. This is characteristically associated with deficiency of _______
questions.solution:
The given image shows corneal vascularization, which is characteristic of Riboflavin deficiency.

Other features include glossitis, cheilosis, and photophobia collectively called ariboflavinosis. A functional test of riboflavin status is done by measuring the activity of erythrocyte glutathione reductase (EGR), EGR activity coefficient (Ratio of EGR activity after adding FAD to the EGR activity without the addition of FAD) > 1.4 is a strong indicator of deficiency.

Image: Cheilosis and glossitis

questions.text: You notice the following lesion in the forearm of an otherwise normal newborn. The lesion is caused because of:

choices.text: A viral infection transmitted from mother to the fetus
A bacterial infection transmitted from the mother to the fetus
Vigorous in utero sucking upon the affected part
An autoimmune condition in the newborn

questions.solution:
The image shows Sucking Blisters and are caused due to vigorous in utero sucking on the affected part.

They are usually present upon the upper-limb.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

10. Hymenal tags

11. Physiological phimosis

12. Conjunctival hemorrhage

13. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: A concerned mother brings her 15-day old baby to you with complaints of decreased activity and vomiting. On examination, the baby is hypotensive, has depressed fontanelles and reduced skin turgor. The image of the external genitalia of the baby is shown below. Which metabolic abnormality can you expect to see in this baby?
questions.solution:
The image shows ambiguous genitalia. This along with signs of dehydration and hypotension suggest congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Hyperkalemia and hyponatremia (due to mineralocorticoid deficiency) can be seen in this condition. 

21-hydroxylase enzyme hydroxylates progesterone and 17-hydroxyprogesterone to yield 11-deoxycorticosterone and 11-deoxycortisol, respectively. They help in the synthesis of aldosterone and cortisol. Therefore, the deficiency of this enzyme leads to the deficiencies of aldosterone and cortisol.

Also, the accumulated steroid precursors are diverted into the pathway for androgen (testosterone) production.

Clinical profile in 21-hydroxylase deficiency:

  • Aldosterone deficiency: Salt-wasting crises (hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypotension, and metabolic acidosis)
  • Cortisol deficiency: Hypoglycemia, hyperpigmentation (due to increased ACTH production), weight loss, weakness, anorexia, vomiting, and shock
  • Androgens excess: Virilization of females and precocious puberty in males

Without treatment, shock, cardiac arrhythmias, and death may occur within days or weeks.

Related Pearl: Variants of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

21-Hydroxylase deficiency

 17-Hydroxylase deficiency 11β-Hydroxylase disease 3β-HSD

Deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone;

↑ in testosterone

 Deficiency of cortisol and sex hormones; ↑ in aldosterone Deficiency of cortisol; ↑ in deoxycorticosterone (mineralocorticoid) and testosterone Deficiency of cortisol, aldosterone and testosterone; ↑ in DHEA
Salt wasting crises Salt retention and  hypertension

Salt retention and  hypertension

 Salt-wasting crises
Virilization of females (ambiguous genitalia 46XX)     Failure of sexual development in females at puberty Virilization of females  (ambiguous genitalia 46XX) Females are mildly
virilized (DHEA is a weak androgen)
Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY) Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY)

Note: In 11β-Hydroxylase deficiency, Aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: You notice the following response on stroking one side of the spine. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this?

choices.text: The reflex elicited is known as galant reflex
The right side of spine has been stroked in the image
Persistence of the reflex interferes with walking movements

questions.solution:
The image shows Galant Reflex also known as Lateral Trunk incurvation reflex.

It is elicited by holding the newborn in ventral suspension (face down) and stroking along the one side of the spine. The normal reaction is for the newborn to laterally flex toward the stimulated side.

Succinctly, the trunk moves towards the side of stimulus.

It is a spinal reflex,and its persistence interferes with development of normal walking movements and postures

questions.text: Pink tetralogy of fallot is present when there is__________
questions.solution:
In pink or acyanotic tetralogy of fallot, the patient is not visibly cyanotic. It is present when there is mild to moderate right ventricular outflow obstruction and a balanced shunt is present through VSD.

Tetralogy of Fallot: It is the most common cyanotic congenital heart disease.

  • The primary defect is an anterior deviation of the infundibular septum (the muscular septum that separates the aortic and pulmonary outflows).
  • The primary defect gives rise to the 4 anatomical components of TOF which are:
  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD) ( NOT ASD)
  • Obstruction to right ventricular outflow - Pulmonic stenosis (PS)
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)
  • Overriding (or dextroposition) of the aorta
  • Obstruction to pulmonary arterial blood flow is usually at both the right ventricular infundibulum (subpulmonic area) and the pulmonary valve.
  • The degree of pulmonary outflow obstruction determines the degree of the patient’s cyanosis and the age of first presentation.

The heart is typically enlarged and is classically “boot-shaped” due to marked right ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: According to current recommended dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be __________ of total energy intake.
questions.solution:
According to current dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be <10% of total energy intake.

Current dietary guidelines for children and adolescents:

  1. Total fat should account for <30% of total daily energy
  2. Saturated fat less than 10% of total daily energy
  3. Dietary cholesterol <300 mg/day
  4. No trans-fat

questions.text: According to the WHO guidelines, indications for hospital admission in pneumonia in an HIV-negative child are all of the following except?
questions.solution:
The revised 2014 WHO guidelines state that it is safe to treat chest indrawing pneumonia at home.

A child who is HIV positive and has chest indrawing will need to be referred for inpatient treatment. Only those children who have general danger signs are classified as having “severe pneumonia” and need to be referred to a higher level (hospital admission). Danger signs: 

  • Not able to drink 
  • persistent vomiting 
  • convulsions lethargic or unconscious 
  • stridor in a calm child 
  • severe malnutrition

questions.text: You were asked to evaluate a child in a pediatric ward during your internship. You notice, the child was able to make a tower of 6 blocks maximum. What could be the minimum age according to this milestone?
questions.solution:
The milestone of making a tower of  6 blocks is usually attained by 24 months of age.

A child makes a tower of

  • 2 blocks by 15 months
  • 3 blocks by 18 months
  • 6 blocks by 2 years
  • 9 blocks by 3 years

questions.text: Which of the following symbol denotes identical twins in a pedigree chart?
questions.solution:
Option A  denotes monozygotic (identical) twins in a pedigree chart.

Related Pearl: Pedigree symbols

questions.text: Which of the following is classified as Stage X1A in the WHO classification of vitamin A deficiency?
questions.solution:
Stage X1A refers to Conjunctival xerosis in the WHO classification of vitamin A deficiency.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to the level of Stage 2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements.

However, active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: Intramuscular injection of 0.5-1 mg of phytonadione is given to all newborn infants at birth because of a transient deficiency of ________.
questions.solution:
Intramuscular injection of 0.5-1 mg of phytonadione is given to all newborn infants because of a transient deficiency of factor IX.

Hemorrhagic disease of the newborn is caused by a transient deficiency of vitamin K–dependent factors, factors II, VII, IX, and X.

Causes:

  • Lack of free vitamin K from the mother
  • Absence of the bacterial intestinal flora normally responsible for the synthesis of vitamin K.

It is responsive to and prevented by vitamin K therapy (0.5-1 mg of phytonadione).

questions.text: A 1-week-old lethargic neonate was brought to the pediatric OPD, he sleeps more than 3 hours after a feed, passes urine 7-8 times a day, and passes stools up to 5 times a day. He has a weight loss of 5% compared to his birth weight. Which of the following points is a sign of inadequate breastfeeding?

choices.text: Weight loss of 5% to birth weight
Sleeps more than 3 hours after a feed

questions.solution:
Lethargy(sleeping more than 2-3 hours after a feed) is an indicator of inadequate breastfeeding in an infant.

Indicators of inadequate breastfeeding in an infant:

  • Weight loss >7-10% of birth weight
  • Lethargy (sleeping longer than 2–3 hours)
  • Delayed stooling (Less than 4 times/day)
  • Decreased urine output (urinating less than 5–7 times/day)
  • Hypernatremic dehydration
  • Inconsolable crying and increased hunger

Insufficient milk intake could be due to insufficient milk production, failure of established breastfeeding, and health conditions in the infant that prevent proper breast stimulation.

Breastfed neonates usually feed 8–12 times a day, with a minimum of 8 times per day. However, the neonate should be breastfed on demand.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was brought to the ER with concerns that he has ingested a foreign body. X-ray confirms the presence of an open safety pin in the mid esophagus. The child is asymptomatic and hemodynamically stable. The appropriate step in management is ________

choices.text: Urgent endoscopy and removal of the foreign body
Observation for 24 hours, if not passed in feces, then perform endoscopy
Make the child eat bananas and wait for passage of foreign body in stool
Urgent thoracotomy and removal of foreign body

questions.solution:
Sharp objects, button batteries in the esophagus, and foreign bodies associated with respiratory symptoms all mandate urgent endoscopic removal.

Button batteries, in particular, are very dangerous foreign bodies, which must be expediently removed because they can cause:

  • Mucosal injury in 1-hour contact time
  • Involve all layers of the esophagus in 4 hours

Asymptomatic blunt objects and coins lodged in the esophagus can be observed for up to 24 hour in anticipation of passage into the stomach.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought with concerns about his rapid abdominal enlargement. Further investigations reveal, a Wilm's tumor with a tumor thrombus extending to the heart. This would be staged as:
questions.solution:
Wilms tumor with tumor thrombus extending to the inferior vena cava and heart is under the stage-3

Staging of Wilms tumor:

Stage I

Tumor confined to the kidney and completely resected with negative lymph nodes.

Stage II

Tumor extends beyond the kidney but is completely resected with negative margins and lymph nodes.

Stage III

Residual tumor present following surgery confined to the abdomen, including gross or microscopic tumor. Extension of tumor thrombus to Inferior vena cava, including the heart.

Stage IV

Hematogenous metastases (lung, liver, bone, brain, etc.)

or lymph node metastases outside the abdominopelvic region.

Stage V

Bilateral renal involvement by tumor

questions.text: An 8 month-old-child with developmental regression, was brought with repeated epileptic spasms upon arousal. The EEG showed irregular multifocal high-voltage spike and wave activity with a chaotic high-voltage slow background. What does the presentation associate with?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation and EEG interpretation referred to as hypsarrythmia is seen in infantile spasms (West syndrome).

West syndrome starts between the ages of 2 and 12 months and consists of a triad of:

  • Infantile spasms (salaam attacks)
  • Developmental regression
  • Hypsarrythmia (abnormal EEG)

West syndrome is best treated with

  • First-line agents: ACTH injections
  • Second-line agents: Vigabatrin
Disease Typical EEG feature
Lennox-Gastaut syndrome 1-2 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep
Absence seizures 3 Hz spike and slow-wave (spike and dome pattern)
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy 4-5 Hz spike
West syndrome Hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage waves with chaotic background)
